model.name: Florence
model.description: You can ditch any old notions you may have of the Renaissance capital as a frozen-in-amber monument to its various monuments; not only did Florence shake off that fusty reputation a few years ago, it’s now arguably Italy’s most vibrant city. New museums abound, intrepid chefs have reinvented everything from the humble panino to *alta cucina Toscana,* and new municipal oversight has made the *centro storico* infinitely more walkable—all without making a dent in Florence’s timeless, heart-lifting beauty (which, really, is still the best reason to come here).
model.seoName: Things To Do In Florence—Attractions & Travel Guide
model.seoDescription: Plan your trip to Florence with Condé Nast Traveler’s guide to the best hotels, restaurants, and things to do.
model.socialName: Florence City Guide: Where to Eat, Stay, and Play
model.socialDescription: A complete guide to Florence, compiled by Condé Nast Traveler editors.
model.dontMiss:
###Play###


[#hotel: /activities/53eae58c976f8f2d44d58a65]|||
"The Treasures of the Buccellati Foundation" celebrates a collection of jewelry, tiaras, and jeweled chalices inspired by Renaissance pieces from the renowned Milanese family-owned jewelry house. [Pitti Palace](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/florence/pitti-palace), through February 22.
|||


###See###

[#activity: /activities/53eae58cdd4d6a0b75efc77a]|||
"Picasso and Spanish Modernity" at the [Palazzo Strozzi](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/florence/palazzo-strozzi) examines the artist's deep connection to other Spanish modernists such as Joan Miró, Salvador Dalí, Juan Gris. Look for the famous Portrait of Dora Maar (1937). Runs until January 25. 
|||


###Explore###
Without restoration work, experts say [Michelangelo's David is in danger of a catastrophic collapse](http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-michelangelo-david-statue-florence-20140502-story.html) because of microscopic fractures in the sculpture's legs and ankles caused by the footsteps of the millions of tourists who come to see the masterpiece.



###Learn###
Read how some feel the rise of ["low-value tourism" might be irrevocably harming Florence](http://www.independent.co.uk/travel/europe/artisan-italy-florence-and-the-machines-9019959.html) and its local artisans. From *The Independent*.

 
###FYI###
Supplies of Vin Santo, the famous Tuscan dessert wine made from dried grapes, may be low because of [severe storms this fall](http://www.thelocal.it/20141107/italys-holy-wine-falls-prey-to-weather).

fields.name: Maria Shollenbarger
fields.shortBio: London-based contributing editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.*
fields.bio: Born and raised in Los Angeles and educated in New England and Italy, Maria Shollenbarger now calls East London home. She worked at *InStyle*and *Travel + Leisure,* among others, before joining *Condé Nast Traveler* in October 2013. She is the Travel Editor for *How To Spend It,* the luxury supplement to the Financial Times.

featuredShops.name: Loretta Caponi
featuredShops.description: In her large shop in Palazzo Aldobrandini, Caponi produces and sells some of the city's most beautiful lingerie and baby clothes, plus bed, bath, and table linens. A windowed atelier in the back reveals her artisans at work, needles in hand, busily sewing away. A second shop in Piazza Antinori offer more of the designs.
featuredShops.shortDescription: A fantasia of ruffles, bows, and lace in Palazzo Aldobrandini.

featuredShops.name: Pineider
featuredShops.description: This ineffably elegant stationers and accessories maker supplied the Florentine aristocracy and alta borghesia with their correspondence cards and birth announcements for 240 years. You can splurge on a hand-tooled cowhide briefcase or appointment book; but equally, a chic keepsake in the form of 12 embossed notecards or a small quaderno (notebook) can be had for the price of breakfast.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Paper goods from stationers who've been in business for over two centuries.

featuredShops.name: Madova
featuredShops.description: A leather-good capital, Florence is particularly famous for its gloves, and this tiny atelier on the far side of Ponte Vecchio offers some of the best. It's the rare shop that produces its creations on site, with colors styles, embellishments, and linings ranging from the neutral to the exotic.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Skip the market and head to this small atelier across the Arno for superior leather gloves.

featuredShops.name: Salvatore Ferragamo
featuredShops.description: Yes, you can find the shoes, accessories, and fashion items of this beloved Florence-based international brand anywhere in the world. But nothing beats browsing (and buying from) the gorgeous racks at the label's headquarters: The 13th-century Palazzo Spini Feroni. Don't miss the basement-level museum.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Don't miss the basement-level museum at the label's impressive HQ.

stay.hed: The 50 Best Hotels in Italy: Readers' Choice Awards 2014
stay.dek: Luxury, history, style—there's no place like Italy. And there are no places in Italy like these 50 amazing hotels, named the best by our Condé Nast Traveler readers. ([View as list](http://www.cntraveler.com/readers-choice-awards/2014/europe/best-hotels-in-italy-readers-choice-awards-2014).)
stay.seoTitle: The Best Hotels in Italy: Florence, Portofino, Rome, Lake Como, & More
stay.seoDescription: Condé Nast Traveler Readers choose the 50 best hotels in Italy in our 2014 poll.
stay.socialDescription: Luxury, history, style—there's no place like Italy. And there are no places in Italy like these 50 amazing hotels, named the best by our Condé Nast Traveler readers.

items.title: [50. Boscolo Venezia](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/venice/boscolo-venezia)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 81.096

Its location away from the Grand Canal, in a relatively quiet part of Cannaregio, is a good thing: being far from the crowds means an infinitely more peaceful experience. In a city famous for water, the hotel's amazing, 21,000 square foot garden offers a unique terra firma touch. Plus, a free shuttle service will get you to St. Mark's and other attractions daily.

items.title: [49. Westin Europa & Regina, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/venice/westin-europa-and-regina)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.100

Comprising of five interconnected palazzi—it is the amalgamation of the former Hotel Britannia and Hotel Regina—this hotel still manages to feel secluded despite its size and renown. It’s tucked away inside a leafy, hidden courtyard, and guests arrive via a private jetty on the Grand Canal. Its 185 guest rooms are Venetian-inspired, many with private terraces and views over the Canal.

items.title: [48. Luna Hotel Baglioni, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/roma/luna-hotel-baglioni--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.140

This historic, 68-room hotel in the heart of the city is housed in an aristocratic Venetian palace dating back to 1118. Though it’s been through countless transformations over the years, it still brims with original details: ceiling frescoes, ornate stucco walls, Murano chandeliers and antique gold fixtures. Its restaurant, Canova, has won multiple awards for its seasonal, traditional Italian cuisine.

items.title: [47. Capri Palace Hotel & Spa](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/anacapri/capri-palace-hotel---spa)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.143

Located in tranquil, scenic Anacapri—away from the bustle of Capri town—this hotel is a place to relax rather than be seen. Guests can enjoy spa treatments at the world famous Capri Beauty Farm, and lavish dinners at the two-Michelin starred restaurant, L’Olivo. Best of all, Il Riccio, the hotel’s own beach club and restaurant by the Blue Grotto, offers the prettiest sunset views on the island.

items.title: [46. Grand Hotel Majestic, Lake Maggiore](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/lake-maggiore/grand-hotel-majestic)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.169

The aptly-named Grand Hotel Majestic lives up to to the hype with its Belle Epoque splendor, secluded English-style gardens, private beach and jetty on Lake Maggiore. All 80 rooms are decorated in a classical style with lush fabrics, antique furnishings and chandeliers. Ask for a water view—even some of the more basic rooms have them.

items.title: [45. Londra Palace, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/roma/londra-palace--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.489

This neoclassical hotel is situated by Piazza San Marco along the Riva degli Schiavoni, overlooking the Lagoon. Each of its 53 rooms  is thoughtfully decorated with silk brocade walls and Biedermeier furniture. Its popular Do Leoni restaurant serves Classic Venetian fare using fresh ingredients bought from the Rialto Market daily; evening cocktails are served at its wood bar or out on the terrace.

items.title: [44. Westin Excelsior, Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/westin-excelsior--florence)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.525

Located mere steps from the Duomo and the Piazza della Signoria, the Westin occupies one of Florence’s most central locations. Inside, you’ll find a fusion of Tuscan, Empire, and Florentine design influences with marble floors, stained glass, tapestries, and frescoes. Se.Sto on Arno, the hotel’s glass-encased rooftop restaurant, offers five-star Mediterranean cuisine, a selection of over 300 wines, and 360 degree views over Florence and the River Arno.

items.title: [43. Hotel Raphaël, Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/rome/hotel-rapha-l)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.646

With its ivy-covered facade, Mirò-heavy art collection, and Richard Meier-designed suites, it’s obvious that the Raphaël is one classy hotel. Its rooms are sleek rather than flashy or opulent, with a mix of modern and traditional details. Its famous, multi-tired rooftop terrace boasts unmatched views over the Pantheon, Palazzo del Quirinale, Piazza di Spagna and beyond.

items.title: [42. Hotel Santa Caterina, Amalfi](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/pontone/hotel-santa-caterina--amalfi)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.762

Beauty greets you at every turn at this 9th century, Liberty-style hotel: terraces are planted with citrus groves and flower gardens, guest rooms have hand-painted tile floors and colorful silk draperies. Lapis lazuli floors and vine-covered arches accent the open-air Ristorante Al Mare by the pool. The honeymoon suites are the highlight here—they feature sunken jacuzzi tubs overlooking the ocean.

items.title: [41. Grand Hotel Excelsior Vittoria, Sorrento](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/sorrento/grand-hotel-excelsior-vittoria--sorrento)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.908

This 1834 family-owned property is located in Sorrento’s bustling historic center, yet feels like a private, leafy oasis. Rooms are designed in styles ranging from Pompeian to Victorian, with trompe l’oeil walls, parquet floors, and gilded mirrors. Terrazza Bosquet serves Neapolitan dishes using ingredients from the hotel's own garden; there’s also a famous terrace bar overlooking the Gulf of Naples and Mount Vesuvius.

items.title: [40. Il San Pietro di Positano](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/vettica-maggiore/il-san-pietro-di-positano)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 83.038

From a distance, Il San Pietro appears as if it’s been hewn into the craggy cliff on which it rests. Each of its rooms has its own private terrace and boasts a picturesque view over the Bay of Positano. An elevator built into the rocks leads guests down to a private beach and to the dreamy Carlino restaurant.

items.title: [39. Il Falconiere, Cortona](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/cortona/il-falconiere--cortona--tuscany)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 83.750

Originally only a restaurant, this 17th century villa located outside Cortona has been owned and managed by the same family since 1860. It now features 29 acres of landscaped gardens, vineyards and olive groves, and naturally, there’s an on-site winery that’s open daily for tastings. Rooms are rustic chic, and decorated with a mix of antiques and traditional textiles.

items.title: [38. Ca' Sagredo Hotel, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/roma/ca-sagredo-hotel--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 83.770

Ca' Sagredo looks more like a palace than a hotel with its marble staircases, wall friezes, gilded ceilings and 42 deeply posh guest rooms. Half of it is actually a museum, highlighting the paintings of 17th and 18th-century artists like Sebastiano Ricci and Giambattista Tiepolo. Don’t miss dinner at the scenic L’Alcova restaurant, where ingredients are bought daily at the Rialto Market across the street.

items.title: [37. Hotel Buca di Bacco, Positano](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/positano/hotel-buca-di-bacco--positano)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 83.869

Framed by rocky hills on the sandy shores of Spiaggia Grande, this hotel makes for the perfect Positano beach getaway—the ocean is literally steps from your door. Rooms are understated, but the spectacular Tyrrhenian sea views make up for it. The Buca di Bacco restaurant, which serves up innovative Amalfi Coast-inspired cuisine, is locally-loved.

items.title: [36. Le Sirenuse, Positano](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/positano/le-sirenuse--positano)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 83.872

This legendary Amalfi Coast hotel is known for its impeccable, Moorish baroque style: whitewashed walls, vaulted ceilings, and mosaic-tiled rooms filled with museum-worthy antiques. The pool terrace, decorated with lemon trees and flowers, is equally picturesque. Small, thoughtful touches like cocktails served in handblown Murano glasses make this hotel extra special.

items.title: [35. Hassler Roma](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/quartiere-monte-sacro/hassler--rome)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 83.941

Built at the top of the Spanish Steps in 1885, the Hassler is considered one of the city’s most iconic properties and is almost as photographed as the steps themselves. Inside, you’ll find elegant rooms decorated with lush silk draperies, Venetian lamps, Limoges porcelain, and velvet headboards. The sixth-floor restaurant, Imàgo, serves up excellent regional cuisine with panoramic Eternal City views.

items.title: [34. Grand Hotel des Iles Borromees, Lake Maggiore](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/lake-maggiore/grand-hotel-des-iles-borromees)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.011

This hotel is grand by name and nature, from its ornate Art Nouveau architecture to its lush, sculpture-adorned gardens. Its corridors are lined with paintings, tapestries, and statues, and each of its 179 rooms and suites boast views over Lake Maggiore or the distant Alps. Some might say it’s borderline ostentatious, but we think that’s what makes it so fabulous.

items.title: [33. Belmond Grand Hotel Timeo, Taormina, Sicily](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/taormina/grand-hotel-timeo--taormina)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.127

This villa-style hotel is said to have been the select escape of aristocrats and Hollywood royals like Catherine Deneuve and Robert De Niro. Not that we’re surprised—it’s highly secluded, perched high in the rocky hills on the eastern coast of Sicily, offering the island’s finest vistas. Inside, there are 70 Sicilian Baroque-style rooms with private terraces overlooking the Bay of Naxos, the ancient Greek Theatre, and Mount Etna.

items.title: [32. Hotel Lungarno, Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/hotel-lungarno--florence)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.229

Unlike many five-star hotels in the area, the Hotel Lungarno feels understatedly and effortlessly stylish—it is, after all, owned by the family of designer Salvatore Ferragamo. Its bright, airy rooms are decorated in clean yellow and ivory tones and feature picture-perfect vistas over the Ponte Vecchio and River Arno. Keep your eyes peeled for its impressive art collection, featuring works by Picasso and Cocteau.

items.title: [31. Hotel de Russie, Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/vatican-city/hotel-de-russie--rome)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.633

Located between the Spanish Steps and Piazza del Popolo, the 89-room Hotel de Russie is in the center of the action—though you wouldn’t know it from the inside. From its quiet courtyard garden to a relaxing five-star spa (featuring sauna and hammam), the entire place simply breathes tranquility. The hotel's restaurant, Le Jardin de Russie, is set in a “secret garden” and specializes in traditional Roman seafood dishes.

items.title: [30. St. Regis Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/quartiere-monte-sacro/st--regis-rome)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.703

The St. Regis is in many ways fabulous, but its trump card is its unmatched attention to detail. From stylish touches like Murano glass lamps and painted frescoes, to the original artwork by Luca Pignatelli, Ubaldo Bartolini and Paolo Fiorentino, each of its 138 guest rooms and 23 suites feel unique and personal. The hotel’s Le Grand bar is considered by many as Rome’s best; order their signature Mediterranean Bloody Mary and decide for yourself.

items.title: [29. Palazzo Victoria, Verona](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/verona/palazzo-victoria)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.752

Just a short stroll from Castelvecchi Castle, Casa di Giulietta (Juliet’s house) and Porta Borsari, this 14th century palace-turned-hotel couldn’t have been built in a more beautiful or historical location. Its 71 guest rooms match the splendor of its surrounds, featuring sumptuous decor, original frescoes and marble soaking tubs. At the hotel restaurant, Borsari 36, guests can admire the Roman remains beneath them through Plexiglass inserts while enjoying seasonal Venetian cuisine.

items.title: [28. St. Regis Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/st--regis-florence)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 85.251

The St. Regis is considered one of Florence’s most treasured structures, and it’s no wonder—the majestic 14th century palazzo was designed by the legendary Renaissance architect Filippo Brunelleschi himself. Each of its 80 guest rooms and 19 suites boast posh Florentine decor; some even offer step-out balconies and views over the River Arno. Its wine cellar, Cantinetta, is set inside a medieval cave, features over 300 wines, and is open for daily tastings.

items.title: [27. BAUERs Il Palazzo, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/roma/bauer-il-palazzo--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 85.514

This hotel’s opulent, gothic-style facade teases passersby with a small glimpse of the grandeur that lies within. There are dripping Murano glass chandeliers hanging from trompe l'oeil ceilings, gilded mirrors set against silk-lined walls, 18th-century Venetian furnishings—no luxury has been spared here. Many of its 38 guest rooms and 34 suites offer panoramic vistas over the Grand Canal, where there’s a private dock for guests making trips to the nearby Palladio Spa.

items.title: [27. Bauers Il Palazzo, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/roma/bauer-il-palazzo--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 85.514

This hotel’s opulent, gothic-style facade teases passersby with a small glimpse of the grandeur that lies within. There are dripping Murano glass chandeliers hanging from trompe l'oeil ceilings, gilded mirrors set against silk-lined walls, 18th-century Venetian furnishings—no luxury has been spared here. Many of its 38 guest rooms and 34 suites offer panoramic vistas over the Grand Canal, where there’s a private dock for guests making trips to the nearby Bauer Palladio Spa.

items.title: [26. Hotel Helvetia & Bristol, Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/hotel-helvetia---bristol--florence)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 85.940

Set in a historic palazzo mere steps from the Duomo, Ponte Vecchio, and Via Tornabuoni, the Helvetia might just be the best-placed hotel in all of Florence. In addition to magnificent city views, all 67 of its rooms are lavishly adorned with silk brocade fabrics, handpicked antique furniture, 17th-century Florentine paintings, and crystal chandeliers. If that weren’t enough, there’s also an excellent restaurant onsite specializing in authentic Tuscan cuisine.

items.title: [25. Belmond Hotel Splendido & Splendido Mare, Portofino](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/santa-margherita-ligure/hotel-splendido---splendido-mare--portofino)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 85.972

The setting lives up to the name at this two-building property. One part of the hotel, on a hillside, is a 16th-century former monastery once attacked by Saracen pirates; the Mare half is on the town's piazzetta by the lively harbor. Rooms mostly come with balconies; some offer panoramic views of Portofino cove. Don’t miss the heated saltwater pool. La Terrazza specializes in local seafood dishes.

items.title: [24. Grand Hotel Villa Serbelloni, Lake Como](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/bellagio/grand-hotel-villa-serbelloni--lake-como)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.126

Although Lake Como can feel ultra-private and secluded,  the Grand Hotel Villa Serbelloni makes it feel like the center of the world. The hotel offers regular excursions to Bergamo, Lugano, Saint Moritz, and the Borromean Islands, but it’s also worth staying put in the evenings to take in the nightly live music in the lounge or a cleansing visit to the sauna.

items.title: [23. Grand Hotel Tremezzo, Lake Como](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/lake-como/grand-hotel-tremezzo--lake-como)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.179

This 80-room, 12-suite Art Nouveau-style hotel has panoramic windows that offer 360-degree views of Lake Como. But you will be so busy taking in the three swimming pools, six restaurants and cafes, and exclusive golf course that you might not have time to stalk George Clooney.

items.title: [22. Jumeirah Grand Hotel Via Veneto, Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/rome/jumeirah-grand-hotel-via-veneto)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.190

Via Veneto was once the city’s party thoroughfare immortalized in some of Fellini's classic films, but nowadays it’s a much more tame affair - lined with embassies and private palazzi. This hotel makes a great launch pad into the city, but offerings like a roof terrace and plenty of nooks to hide away in, creates a nice sense of intimacy as well.

items.title: [21. Grand Hotel Villa Cora, Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/grand-hotel-villa-cora)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.250

A wedding gift from a baron to his lucky bride, this luxurious 19th century property continues to feel like a private home, albeit one with 46-rooms kitted out with neoclassical treasures. Despite being on the outskirts of town, a complimentary shuttle bus makes it easy to access the city center.

items.title: [20. Grand Hotel Continental, Siena](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/sienna/grand-hotel-continental--siena--tuscany)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.416

Located in the heart of Siena, near the city’s famed Campo, this historic property comes with plenty of original grand details—frescos, period artwork, and a 17th century ballroom—alongside more modern amenities. Don’t miss the stylish wine bar.

items.title: [19. Four Seasons Hotel Milano](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/milan/four-seasons-hotel-milano)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.529

Close to the city’s legendary shopping area,  Montenapoleone, this property makes an excellent choice for business travelers and families with younger kids in tow, with amenities for both, and the kind of warm but professional service that the northern city can sometimes lack.

items.title: [18. Park Hatt Milan](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/milan/park-hyatt-milan)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.537

If you need a break from the somewhat chintzy and overblown style of some other Milanese favorites you've come to the right place. Here, clean lines and soothing colors create a cocooning effect and the multi-lingual staff exemplifies the kind of spot-on service the brand has made famous worldwide.

items.title: [17. Tuscany Firenze](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/florence/tuscany-firenze)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.657

A member of the Starhotels group, the Tuscany Firenze is located in the business district of northern Florence near the airport. What this modern hotel may lack in local charm it more than makes up for as an excellent, affordable option for early morning flight arrivals or departures - including good food at Assaggi restaurant and a cozy, leather armchair-filled bar.

items.title: [16. Belmond Villa San Michele, Fiesole-Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/fiesole/villa-san-michele--fiesole)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.836

Sitting up in the hills of Florence’s Fiesole, this former monastery remains one of Italy’s most legendary hotels mainly because of the feeling of being in its own idyllic world floating above the Renaissance city, with landscaped gardens, an excellent cooking school, and pool. One could almost forget all the attractions right outside the gates.

items.title: [15. Belmond Hotel Cipriani, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/lido/hotel-cipriani--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.856

This legendary property on Venice’s Giudecca continues to draw A-listers for its Olympic size pool, old school white glove service, and romantic gardens that seem a million miles from the throngs in Saint Mark’s Square (but it’s only a short boat away). Rooms in the main building recently received a necessary update to restore them to their former glory.

items.title: [14. Grand Hotel Convento di Amalfi](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/amalfi/grand-hotel-convento-di-amalfi)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.951

Perched on top of a cliff facing the sea, one can’t help but be a bit jealous of the nuns who once called this home. But of course they didn’t have the same amenities—a pool overlooking the water, the restaurant Dei Cappucini with its sweeping views, a hammam and gym.

items.title: [13. JK Place, Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/j--k--place--florence)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 87.037

The model for an intimate boutique hotel, this 20-room hideaway sits on the beautiful piazza of Santa Maria Novella with an outdoor terrace facing the famed church, a cozy library with a fireplace, and incredibly chic rooms kitted out by famed Italian designer Michele Bonan.

items.title: [12. Belmond Hotel Caruso, Ravello](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/ravello/hotel-caruso--ravello)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 87.331

This eleventh-century villa sits high above the town of Ravello overlooking the vertiginous Amalfi Coast. Should you feel like coming down from the heights, there’s plenty to see and do here: the hotel will take you to Positano or Pompeii via its boat, Ercole (Italian for “Hercules”) or you can sign up for a three-hour guided Vespa tour of the town by night. A full restoration transformed this Moorish-influenced palazzo into a property as dazzling as its location. The frescoes burst with color, the gardens are a sensory bonanza, and the extraordinary infinity pool makes it seem as if you could float out to the turquoise sea a thousand feet below. Add to all this a stunning terrace restaurant and superb service and it’s hard to imagine leaving.

items.title: [12. Belmond Hotel Caruso, Ravello](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/ravello/hotel-caruso--ravello)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 87.331

This eleventh-century villa sits high above the town of Ravello overlooking the vertiginous Amalfi Coast. Should you feel like coming down from the heights, there’s plenty to see and do here: the hotel will take you to Positano or Pompeii via its boat, Ercole (Italian for “Hercules”) or you can sign up for a three-hour guided Vespa tour of the town by night.

items.title: [11. Capri Hotel Caesar Augustus](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/anacapri/capri-hotel-caesar-augustus)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 87.619

Location location location. Sitting 1000-feet up over the Bay of Naples, the views from this former mansion are stupendous from every vantage point, particularly from the spectacular bi-level infinity pool. (NB: not the best choice for kids in tow because of strict hours at said pool and lots of steps.)

items.title: [10. Four Seasons Hotel Firenze](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/florence/four-seasons-hotel-firenze--florence)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 88.756

One of the most beautiful properties in Italy—with two historic buildings linked by the largest private garden in Florence—comes with impeccable service, wonderful amenities including a spa and pool, and an atmosphere that feels like an oasis after the tourist mayhem of the city center.

items.title: [9. Aldrovandi Villa Borghese, Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/parioli/aldrovandi-villa-borghese--rome)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 88.983

Surrounded by one of Rome’s most picturesque of parks near the recently restored Borghese Museum, the Aldrovandi comes with a two-Michelin starred restaurant, a brand new spa and pool, and bikes to tool around the Eternal City.

items.title: [8. San Domenico Palace Hotel, Sicily](http://cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/catania/san-domenico-palace-hotel--taormina)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 89.524

Formerly a 15th-century monastery, this hotel now doesn’t seem to have a problem embracing vice. There are two fully-stocked bars, including one next to the pool, three restaurants, and lush gardens with plenty of hidden corners that lovers can sequester themselves in complete privacy. Set on the slopes of Mount Etna overlooking the Ionian Sea, rooms are converted monk's cells flanking long, arched corridors (some with private terraces).

items.title: [7. Hotel Splendide Royal, Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/rome/hotel-splendide-royal)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 89.796

Close to many of the city’s musts—The Spanish Steps, Villa Borgese, and Piazza del Popolo—the Splendide is the kind of address that makes you feel like you are living at a nobleman’s home. This 19th-century palace is lavishly decorated - marble floors, Murano chandeliers, gilt mirrors, and rooms (many with terraces) overlooking greenery. The Mirabelle restaurant, under the guidance of chef Bruno Borghesi, serves modern Mediterranean cuisine with sweeping city views.

items.title: [6. Castello Banfi il Borgo, Tuscany](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/poggio-alle-mura/castello-banfi-il-borgo--montalcino)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 90.476

In many ways the Banfi vineyard put Tuscany’s priceless Brunello on the oenophile map. Now you can also appreciate the hospitality of the estate with its castle digs, two restaurants, and of course, tastings of their vintages.

items.title: [5. The Gritti Palace (Luxury Collection), Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/roma/hotel-gritti-palace--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 90.507

When young men and women used to travel through Europe on their Grand Tour, Venice was a popular stop along the way. Keeping that aesthetic in mind, the Gritti Palace – which recently underwent a $50 million renovation – features suites inspired by famous guests like Ernest Hemingway and Somerset Maugham, and an elegant rooftop bar where guests can mingle while sipping heady cocktails.

items.title: [4. Grand Hotel Miramare, Santa Margherita Ligure](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/santa-margherita-ligure/grand-hotel-miramare--portofino)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 91.675

This 1903, Art Nouveau hotel’s crisp white and blue exterior offsets the Genoan landscape, but the real jewel is the garden filled with camellias, oleander, cedar, and fragrant lavender. Rooms and suites (some with balconies with views of the Golfo del Tiguillo or park) are calming and elegant. Every spring, the community holds a welcoming festival for warmer weather complete with bonfires, fireworks, and – best of all – pancakes.

items.title: [3. Palazzo Avino, Ravello](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/castiglione-di-ravello/palazzo-avino--formerly-palazzo-sasso---ravello)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 95.089

Formerly the Palazzo Sasso, this Amalfi Coast jewel continues to shine with some of the most gorgeous sea views in Italy (best enjoyed from the twin Jacuzzis), period pieces from the 17th century, and a Michelin-starred restaurant. Another draw? The property’s proximity to Ravello, arguably this coast’s most charming town.

items.title: [2. Castello di Casole, Tuscany](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/casole-d-elsa/castello-di-casole--casole-d-elsa)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 95.332

This 4200-acre estate outside Siena is a blend of ancient and modern, with big-screen TVs, iPod docking stations, and rain showers located inside a restored fifteenth-century castle and surrounding buildings. The estate still produces its own olive oils and wine and offers in-season wild boar hunting expeditions.

items.title: [1. Il Salviatino, Fiesole-Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/fiesole/il-salviatino)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 95.500

A hideaway in Florence’s suburban Fiesole neighborhood, this historic villa includes 12-acres of landscaped gardens, a spa, and beautifully restored rooms with original marble floors and frescos, alongside custom king beds and deep soaking tubs. If you want to splurge, go for one of the penthouses, one of Kate Moss’s preferred crash pads.

items.title: 50. Boscolo Venezia
items.caption: Readers' Rating

featuredEats.name: Il Santo Bevitore
featuredEats.description: A relative newcomer, this popular, stylish spot on the south side of the Arno (the neighborhood called Oltrarno) pulls in local hipsters and tuned-in tourists for its nouveau-rustic osteria fare and laid-back atmosphere. The food is based on fresh, locally sourced produce, and it's as good a spot for a glass of wine and plate of cheese and salumi as for a full meal. Either way, do leave room for the great desserts.
featuredEats.cuisine: Local or Regional, Haute Cuisine or Molecular Gastronomy
featuredEats.shortDescription: You'll find traditional Florentine dishes and more modern flavors at this Oltrarno spot.

featuredEats.name: Trattoria Sostanza (Il Troia)
featuredEats.description: This full-of-charm hole-in-the-wall—a Florence classic for nearly 150 years—offers just six tables (so do book ahead) and has had the same staff for the past two decades. Try the famous artichoke omelet and the beloved butter chicken.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Don't leave Florence without stopping by this tiny trattoria to try their famous butter chicken.

featuredEats.name: Zeb
featuredEats.description: Once a humble deli, the tiny, casual, family-run Zeb—on the south side of the Arno—offers a variety of hearty, hot and cold Tuscan dishes: huge, overstuffed ravioli filled with seasonal produce and local cheeses, long-braised meats, including lampredotto (a local delicacy similar to tripe that's made from the fourth stomach of the cow), and perfectly cooked vegetables. The contemporary atmosphere retains a deli feel, with stools arranged along two sides of a central island whose other side still traffics in to-go gourmet items.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Come here for classics like pappa al pomodoro, ribollita and—for the adventurous—lampredotto.

featuredEats.name: ‘ino
featuredEats.description: Hidden between the Uffizi and Ponte Vecchio, this daytime wine bar makes a great lunch spot. Pair a glass of something local with a wood-fire-baked focaccia panini filled with such ingredients as gorgonzola and radicchio. The place also offers to-go gourmet delights and specialty foods.
featuredEats.cuisine: Local or Regional, Sandwiches, Soup, Salads, or Snacks
featuredEats.shortDescription: Chef Alessandro Frassica makes arguably some of the best panini in Florence at this lunch spot.

contributorsAuthor.name: Maria Shollenbarger
contributorsAuthor.shortBio: London-based contributing editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.*
contributorsAuthor.bio: Born and raised in Los Angeles and educated in New England and Italy, Maria Shollenbarger now calls East London home. She worked at *InStyle*and *Travel + Leisure,* among others, before joining *Condé Nast Traveler* in October 2013. She is the Travel Editor for *How To Spend It,* the luxury supplement to the Financial Times.

eat.dek: Just because you’re eating gelato in Italy doesn’t automatically mean it’s authentic or even any good. Unfortunately, many gelaterias continue to pass off subpar, factory-made junk as the real deal, so [we have a guide to help you with that](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-06-27/gelato-italian-ice-cream-explained). That said, Italy still abounds with artisans who serve up fresh, handmade, all-natural gelato daily. Below, we’ve handpicked the places where you’ll find the best gelato in Italy, from Rome to Milan to Florence (where gelato was created).

items.title: [La Carraia ](www.lacarraiagroup.eu)
items.caption:
Florence


----------


Florence is the birthplace of gelato, so it’s no surprise that two of the country’s best gelaterias are here. Many locals swear that La Carraia, located slightly off the beaten path on the Oltrarno side of Ponte alla Carraia, is home to the best gelato anywhere, period. It's almost supernaturally creamy and the flavors are intense; you’ll be hard pressed to find dark chocolate gelato this dense or decadent anywhere else (except perhaps at Milan’s Il Massimo). Portions are generous, and prices are low: you can score a small cone for just €1. (*Piazza Nazario Sauro, 25r, Florence; +39 055 280695*)

items.title: [Gelateria I Caruso](www.gelatoicaruso.it)
items.caption:
Rome


----------


I Caruso may no longer be a local secret, but brave the long lines and go anyway. You can’t get gelato much fresher than this: it’s made on-site, while you watch through a glass window. Flavors are a mixture of traditional and seasonal—melon, mandarin orange, and pineapple gelato steal the show in the summer—and they’ll top your gelato with fresh whipped cream, either regular or flavored with *zabaglione* (a sweet marsala wine). (*Via Collina, 13-1, Rome; +39 06 4201 6420*)

items.title: [La Sorbetteria Castiglione](www.lasorbetteria.it)
items.caption:
Bologna


----------


It's no wonder that this gelateria has expanded to two other locations—its stunning quality and innovative flavors have locals and now tourists flocking steadily in droves. The standout flavor here is the Dolce Emma, honey-caramelized figs and lemon tucked into silky ricotta gelato, closely followed by the Dolce Contagio, crisp candied walnuts in an earthy pine nut gelato. If you're looking for a lighter option, the seasonal fruit sorbettos are magnificent. (*Via Castiglione, 44, Bologna; +39 051 233257*)

items.title: [Alberto Marchetti](www.albertomarchetti.it)
items.caption:
Turin


----------


Locals swear that the gelato at Alberto Marchetti is the freshest-tasting in town, and they’re probably right: all his gelato is served within 24 hours of it being made in-house. Marchetti takes pride in using seasonal ingredients of the highest quality and even publishes the ingredient list for every flavor on his website. His gelato is surprisingly cheap, too—only €2 for a small cone with up to two flavors. We recommend the terrific *fior di latte* (mozzarella made from cow's milk) and farina bona, a surprisingly pleasant flour flavor, reminiscent of toasted corn. (*Corso Vittorio Emanuele II, 2, Torino; +39 011 839 0879*)

items.title: Gelateria Alaska
items.caption:
Venice


----------


This tiny gelato temple might be tucked away from the crowds in Santa Croce, but it’s well worth the trek. The quality is superb, the flavors are daring—think ginger, rosewater, celery, cardamom and artichoke—and the owner, Carlo Pistacchi, is unfailingly hilarious and charming. The consistency of Alaska’s gelato is noticeably lighter and less dense than others on this list—but certainly without compromise to the fullness of its flavor. (*Calle Larga de Bari, 1159, Venice; +39 041 715211*)

items.title: [Emilia Cremeria](www.cremeriaemilia.com)
items.caption:
Parma


----------


You have to use your imagination at Emilia Cremeria: instead of the typical mountains of gelato on display at most touristy gelaterias, theirs is packed tightly into covered silver containers and you won’t even see it until you’ve ordered. But don’t panic: this safekeeping—the true mark of authentic gelato—ensures you’ll sink your fangs into the freshest, coldest gelato possible. It’s a perfect contrast to the warm, gooey, melted chocolate that they pour into your cone before heaping it with generous scoops of gelato. (*Via Farini, 29, Parma; +39 0521 207316*)

items.title: [Come il Latte](www.comeillatte.it)
items.caption:
Rome


----------


Despite having opened only a couple of years ago, Come il Latte is already a serious contender in the gelato game. Though it’s located in a fairly tourist-congested area—about ten minutes’ walk from Termini station—it’s still that it feels somewhat hidden. The gelato here is no joke: sinfully rich and almost buttery, with transcendent flavors like mascarpone with biscotti and salted caramel. Like Emilia Cremeria, they’ll also fill your cone with chocolate before your scoop—and will even top the finished product with chocolate too, if you like. (*Via Silvio Spaventa, 24/26, Rome; +39 06 4290 3882*)

items.title: Il Massimo Del Gelato
items.caption:
Milan


----------


Though Il Massimo recently opened a second location, we still recommend the original shopfront on Via Lodovico Castelvetro—it’s bigger and offers more flavors (around 40), made fresh daily. On any given day, eight of those flavors are dedicated purely to chocolate, with variations like 100%, 75%, chocolate almond, chocolate rum, chocolate cherry, chocolate with cinnamon and chilies… you get the idea. Not a chocoholic? Their fruit-based flavors are just as high-impact. (*Via Lodovico Castelvetro, 18, Milan*)

items.title: [Vivoli](www.vivoli.it)
items.caption:
Florence


----------


Having opened in 1929, Vivoli is said to be the oldest gelateria in Florence and is arguably the most famous. If you can get past the smaller portions, heftier prices, and fact that they don’t offer cones, you’ll delight in the deep flavors—*millefoglie* (the Italian take on a Napoleon pastry) and *cassata* (containing dried nuts and/or fruit) are exceptional—and super smooth, velvety texture. (*Via dell’Isole delle Stinche, 7r, Florence; +39 055 292334*)


----------


Did your favorite make our list? If not, share it below in the comments.

fields.name: Krisanne Fordham
fields.shortBio: Krisanne Fordham is a contributing editor at *Condé Nast Traveler*
fields.bio: Krisanne Fordham is a contributing digital editor at *Condé Nast Traveler* and a writer for CNN Travel, *Departures* and *Travel + Leisure.* Previously, she was a staff editor at *Condé Nast Traveler* and The AOL-Huffington Post Media Group. Krisanne grew up in Sydney, Australia and splits her time between New York and Italy.

eat.hed: At This Italian Winery, the Architecture's as Amazing as the Chianti
eat.dek: Tuscany's Cantina Antinori winery boasts architecture that's as amazing as their wines. Here's how to turn a visit into a relaxing and luxurious weekend trip.
eat.seoTitle: At This Italian Winery, the Architecture's as Amazing as the Chianti
eat.seoDescription: Tuscany's Cantina Antinori winery boasts architecture that's as amazing as their wines. Here's how to turn a visit into a relaxing and luxurious weekend trip.
eat.socialTitle: At This Italian Winery, the Architecture's as Amazing as the Chianti
eat.socialDescription: Tuscany's Cantina Antinori winery boasts architecture that's as amazing as their wines. Here's how to turn a visit into a relaxing and luxurious weekend trip.
eat.body:
[#image: /photos/53da87746dec627b149f0742]|||The terra-cotta bricks used to build Cantina Antinori match the earthy tones of the Tuscan hillside.|||

Antinori is one of the biggest names in Italian wine, but it’s not just the Chianti that’s drawing visitors to their hillside winery near the village of Bargino, 20 minutes outside Florence. The winemaker’s new state-of-the-art, cantilevered headquarters, [Cantina Antinori](http://www.antinorichianticlassico.it/en), is luring architecture buffs who are as interested in the Archea-designed structure as they are in a fine Super Tuscan. [Archea](http://www.archea.it/en/), one of Italy’s leading architecture firms, gave Antinori a space that both makes a statement, and alludes to the colors and terrain of the surrounding, gently hilly landscape. Here’s how to make a weekend out of your visit.






##### **Stay**


The new 41-room [Castello di Casole](http://www.castellodicasole.com/) occupies a restored tenth-century castle in the heart of Tuscany and is surrounded by 4,200 acres of vineyards and olive trees. Don’t leave before taking a plunge in the infinity pool overlooking the spectacular valley (_888-548-9429; doubles from $440_).





[#image: /photos/53da8774dcd5888e145ba2bf]|||Italian wine producer Antinori has been harvesting grapes in Tuscany since the Renaissance, but with its new Cantina Antinori—a wine museum, auditorium, cellar, tasting room, and restaurant in one architectural triumph—all eyes are on the region’s future.|||
##### **Eat**


[Oreade](http://monteverdituscany.com/ristorante-oreade/) is the newest addition to Monteverdi, a collection of rental villas, a hotel, and a bar in the tiny hilltop hamlet of Castiglioncello del Trinoro. It has sweeping views of the Val d’Orcia and classic Tuscan dishes like _bistecca alla fiorentina_ (_Via di Mezzo 8; 39- 0578-268-146; entrées from $33_).






##### **Drink**


The brainchild of the owners of Siena’s well-known Osteria le Logge restaurant, **Un Tubo** is part wine bar and part performing arts space tucked into an ancient cellar. There’s jazz, theater, and readings throughout the week (_Via del Luparello 2, Siena_).






##### **Bring Back**


The soft leather bags at Pienza’s [Officine 904](http://www.officine904.it/) are the embodiment of Tuscan artisanship (_Via Dogali 16_).










Photos by Matt Hranek

fields.name: Ondine Cohane
fields.shortBio: Contributing editor [Ondine Cohane](www.ondinecohane.com) is based in Tuscany—when not doing a round-the-world trip each winter.
fields.bio: After [Ondine Cohane](www.ondinecohane.com) edited *Conde Nast Traveler's* Word of Mouth section for a couple of years, she got her dream job, a gig as a contributing editor at the magazine. Eating great food, drinking excellent wine, discovering small hotels, exploring far-flung destinations are all part of the gig, and what she loves. Ondine was previously at *New York* magazine, and frequently writes for *The New York Times* travel section as well as *Lonny, Details,* and other magazines. Before Columbia College and Brearley, Ondine's family moved every couple of years, which may partially explain the wanderlust.

eat.hed: Don’t Leave Florence Without Eating This One Dish
eat.dek: Surprise: It’s not bistecca fiorentina. Find out what traditional dish you should try on your next trip to Florence, Italy.
eat.seoTitle: Don’t Leave Florence Without Eating This One Dish
eat.seoDescription: Surprise: It’s not bistecca fiorentina. Find out what traditional dish you should try on your next trip to Florence, Italy.
eat.socialTitle: Don’t Leave Florence Without Eating This One Dish
eat.socialDescription: Surprise: It’s not bistecca fiorentina. Find out what traditional dish you should try on your next trip to Florence, Italy.
eat.body:
[#image: /photos/53e2f229dddaa35c30f65e91]||||||

**You can’t leave Florence without eating…**



 A tripe sandwich. When musing about food in Florence, most people dream of steak—the renowned bistecca fiorentina—but I reach deeper into the cow and go for any one of its four stomachs. Traditionally, Florentines have been obsessively fond of tripe (and just about other any innards), and no one cooks it better. Trust me, there’s no funkiness, nothing to make your stomach quiver. One of the world’s great dishes is the tomato-sauced_ trippa alla fiorentina_, but there’s even more pleasure in something that most travelers miss: a warm tripe panino on a crusty roll, bought from a food truck or cart and eaten on the street.



**How to order:** A well-stocked tripe wagon will have a surprisingly diverse menu of offal, starring a few different kinds of tripe including the classic of Florence classics (and my favorite): _lampredotto_, made from the ruminant’s fourth stomach. Ask for the roll to be _bagnato_ (dipped in the cooking broth) and garnished with green sauce: salsa verde, typically made of mixed herbs, anchovies, capers, garlic, olive oil, and a little vinegar and/or mustard for extra sparkle. For a drink, I’d opt for a glass of white wine or, on a really hot day, a beer.





[#image: /photos/53e2f229c2d3f39d3610b4a0]|||Vegetarians, beware.|||

**How to eat it:** First, put aside any memories you may have (or think you have) of stinky tripe. Properly prepared behind the scenes, then cooked to tenderness in flavorful, salty broth and served warm, lampredotto will remind you more of super-tender juicy corned brisket than of a so-called variety meat. The salsa verde functions like the mustard on a deli sandwich, but with a more complex flavor. These panini can sometimes be topped with seasonal vegetables too, such as simmered leeks or artichokes, but I prefer my lampredotto clear of distractions. Near the food truck, there will be benches or even a counter on which to lean; if not, just stand there like the other customers. Lean forward so the juice doesn’t drip on your shirt and be sure to have plenty of paper napkins at the ready. Beyond that, heck, it’s a sandwich, and you’ve been eating those since you were two years old.







**Where to find one:** There’s no longer a _trippaio_ on every street corner in Florence. The tradition is robust, but invasive species like hamburgers impinge on its popularity. Still, there are quite a few scattered around the city—wherever there are lawyers or construction workers on a lunch break (this is not a dinner-time tradition). There’s even a small (but good) trippaio right outside one of the town’s best restaurants, Cibrèo, on via dei Macci. But my favorite tripe man is Mario Albergucci, whose elaborate fold-out truck is to be found at the Porta Romana, south of the Pitti Palace and the Boboli Gardens. Like his impeccably clean wagon, his repertoire is larger than average, going beyond tripe to include, for instance, _poppa_ (udder) and even tender simmered beef, veal, or pork for those who just can’t cope with the facts of Florentine life.



**More travel etiquette:**



[The Dish You Should Never Order in Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/05/the-best-food-in-rome)







 [The One Dish to Eat in Naples, Italy](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/06/food-etiquette-guide-eating-in-naples)

featuredPlays.name: Centro di Cultura Contemporanea Strozzina
featuredPlays.description: Downstairs in the basement of the Palazzo Strozzi is Center for Contemporary Culture, the city’s excellent contemporary art museum. You’ll find conventional exhibitions of photography and fine art, but also readings (Michael Cunningham and Jonathan Lethem recently read the works of Italian poets), dance performances, and seasonal installations by the likes of video artist Mark Formanek.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: An oasis of modern art in the heart of Renaissance Florence, near Piazza della Repubblica.

featuredPlays.name: Basilica of Santa Croce
featuredPlays.description: Housing the tombs of many of Florence's most illustrious citizens (Michelangelo and Galileo among them), this 13th-century Franciscan church boasts an impressive and typically Florentine striped façade, vast interiors, an open timber roof, and a beautiful marble pulpit. But it's the 14th-century Giotto frescoes in the Peruzzi and Bardi chapels that most impress.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: Stop here to visit Michelangelo's tomb, then head to nearby Teatro del Sale for lunch.

featuredPlays.name: Piazzale Michelangelo
featuredPlays.description: For a stunning view of Florence, head up to this large piazza's panoramic viewing platform, which perches high above the Arno's south bank. On a clear day, it feels like you can see forever, and even the tour buses and frequent maddening crowds can't diminish that pleasure.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: A 25-minute walk (uphill) from Piazza della Repubblica, it's worth it for the best view of the city.

featuredPlays.name: Basilica of San Lorenzo
featuredPlays.description: The façade of the Medicis' parish church was never completed, but the geometric white-and-gray interior, designed by Brunelleschi, is not to be missed. Also not to be missed: the pair of bronze pulpits by Donatello, the Old Sacristy decorative by Brunelleschi and Donatello, the room-filling staircase of Michelangelo's Laurentian Library, or the Medici tombs of Michelangelo's Sagrestia Nuova.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: This church’s interior is one of the purest expressions of Renaissance architecture in Florence.

cheatSheet.dek: Musn't miss landmarks, museums, and more.

items.dek: Once a 15th-century palace in the Oltrarno, the Pitti Palace now hosts several different museums.
To visit the cathedral is to be awed—especially if you climb the 463 steps to the top of its dome.
This oft-overlooked museum houses what is perhaps the city's best collection of sculpture.
This former convent houses the collection of Stefano Bardini, the city’s most venerated antiquarian.
Climb the steps for views of Florence—along with Fiesole, the forte di Belvedere, and San Miniato.
111 stunning acres of fountains, amphitheater, grottoes, rose gardens and more.

cheatSheet.dek: The best spots for sightseeing—and people watching.

items.dek: The tiny truffle-butter sandwiches at this bar have been a local favorite for literally centuries.
Mingle with the young creative crowd (and partake in a hookah) at this Oltrarno spot near Negroni.
Those looking for a superior espresso—and a shopping break—should try this café on Via della Spada.
Finish your evening with a drink at this rooftop bar, where the views are nearly 360 degrees.
Enjoy a namesake cocktail and snacks on the terrace at this bar in the Oltrarno.
Tucked on a side street just over the Ponte Vecchio, this quiet wine bar is one of the city's best.

cheatSheet.dek: From vintage finds to the latest Italian designs.

items.dek: Florence's central market has produce, meat, and poultry stalls, plus specialty-food shops aplenty.
Bemer’s artisans handcraft shoes on-site and will travel internationally for refitting sessions.
This historic store and museum stocks an incredible selection of perfumes, soaps, and elixirs.
This small boutique carries a well-curated mix of vintage and contemporary designer pieces.
An unorthodox combo—cooking school/design store/vintage shop—that totally works.
Steps from the Ponte Vecchio, this chic café/store mashup has become a place to see and be seen.

miniGuides.dek: How fortunate for all of us that Florence is so small, its centro storico a compact and relatively easy-to-navigate nexus in which the medieval and the Renaissance exist right next to the utterly modern. So three hours here doesn’t have to involve frantic dashing from one end of town to another: a single walk across the Ponte Vecchio gives you just what you want.
miniGuides.socialDescription: Three hours in Florence doesn’t have to involve frantic dashing: a single walk across the Ponte Vecchio gives you just what you want.
miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/548f6057860c74c1162c9bfb]|||The Boboli Gardens are an immaculate, peaceful respite from Florence's crowds.|||



## EAT HERE

__[Caffe Rivoire](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/florence/caffe-rivoire)__ has been a Piazza della Signoria stalwart for a century. Yes, it’s a bit pricey, and yes, it’s fairly formal. But to sit in the square as you consider a view that takes in the nearly 800-year-old façade of the Palazzo Vecchio, the equally old and illustrious barrel vaults of the Loggia dei Lanzi, and the elegant symmetry of the Uffizi galleries—all without having to track your gaze more than about 80 degrees—is a one-of-a-kind experience. And the *cornetti alla marmelata* (the Italian take on a croissant, filled with bitter-orange marmalade), are almost always still warm from the oven. 

##SHOP HERE

 Just a few doors up is __[Pineider](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/florence/pineider)__, the ineffably elegant stationers and accessories maker that’s supplied the Florentine aristocracy and alta borghesia with their correspondence cards and birth announcements for 240 years. You can splurge on a hand-tooled cowhide briefcase or appointment book; but equally, a chic keepsake in the form of 12 embossed notecards or a small *quaderno* (notebook) can be had for the price of breakfast. 



##PLAY HERE

 Brave the hordes along the Ponte Vecchio (and do stop, if just for five seconds, to admire the view down the Arno towards the Cascine Gardens, the enfilade of bridges mirrored perfectly in the jade-green water) and cross over to the Oltrarno, where it’s then just a short stroll to the Palazzo Pitti. This monolith is home to various galleries as well as to Florence’s answer to the Met’s Costume Institute—but it’s the adjacent __[Boboli Gardens](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/florence/boboli-gardens)__ you’re here for. Their 111 acres have lost none of their beauty since Cosimo de’ Medici laid them out—fountains, amphitheater, grottoes, rose gardens and all—as a private playground for his wife, Eleonora di Toledo (with help from the likes of Vasari and Buontalenti).
miniGuides.seoDescription: Three hours in Florence doesn’t have to involve frantic dashing: a single walk across the Ponte Vecchio gives you just what you want.

She is the Travel Editor for *How To Spend It,* the luxury supplement to the Financial Times.

miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/548f6051b6e03e8c2d0cce52]||||||


For a very long time, Florence was a city that felt preserved in amber: its significant beauty aside, it was a place for appreciating monuments and saturating oneself in history, and not much else. How things have changed: today young chefs are re-interpreting old classics in buzzing (and, in one case, Michelin-starred) ways; and provocative contemporary art and glittering fashion houses are showcased in the city’s most staid old palaces. Three leisurely days spent criss-crossing the Arno, from the old market of San Lorenzo to the shaded streets of San Niccolo, with hits of vibrant 21st century life in between, is the ideal way to take it all in.


[#image: /photos/548f6051860c74c1162c9bdd]||||||





##Day 1

__STAY__

__[J.K. Place Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/j--k--place--florence)__ has a prime central location on Piazza Santa Maria Novella, with a front terrace that hums on weekends, when the hotel serves a generous and tasty brunch. Rooms range from cozy doubles to the first-floor front suite, with its massive canopied bed and three French doors that open onto the square. The décor is terrifically chic, with large-scale photos by Massimo Listri throughout.

__DRINK__

 Though it’s affiliated with the winery of the same name, it’s the coffee at __[Cantina dei Verrazzano](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/florence/cantina-dei-verrazzano)__ that is a reliably good experience: a nice setting (coffered and beamed ceilings, terracotta floors, heavy walnut tables and chairs) meets expertly prepared *macchiati,*along with a selection of very fresh pastries and some excellent people watching. 

__EAT__

__[I 13 Gobbi](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/florence/i-13-gobbi)__ has been around—and in lots of guidebooks—for a long time; but its formula of straightforward Tuscan classics still draws a contingent of home-grown fans. The setting is straight-up rusticity—beamed ceilings, *mattone*brick walls, bottles stacked on crates—and very charming. Go at lunch, when it’s easier to get a table in the courtyard, and focus on the meat and game dishes until April rolls around, when it’s all about the fava beans. 

__PLAY__

The buzzy __San Niccolo__ district, on the Oltrarno—Florence’s Rive Gauche—is also one of its most atmospheric, with steep paths winding up towards Piazzale Michelangelo above, and, down at street level, patrician palaces lining the cobbled streets. Here, the __[Museo Bardini](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/florence/museo-bardini)__ is an unsung gem, a former convent housing the collection of Stefano Bardini, the city’s most venerated antiquarian. There are beautiful 15th through 17th century gems (note the preponderance of Della Robbia), and a huge collection of medieval armor and weapons guaranteed to thrill the under-12’s. 

Afterward, if you’re feeling in form, walk east along the Arno to climb the 160 steps to the top of the 14th-century __[Torre di San Niccolo](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/florence/torre-di-san-niccolo)__; from its summit you’ll have 200-degree views of Florence – along with Fiesole to the north, the forte di Belvedere, and San Miniato. 

__EAT__

The mood is cheerily boisterous at __[Il Santo Bevitore](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/florence/il-santo-bevitore)__, where Tuscan standards get sophisticated (witness what might be the city’s finest pappa al pomodoro, a smooth, spoon-able paean to bread and tomatoes). There are also nods to other Italian regions—the rigatoni with eye-wateringly spicy ‘nduja sausage, for instance, matches perfectly with a woodsy, mineral Aglianico del Vulture from the excellent wine list. Tip: Book in the small, much quieter back room if you want a tete-a-tete; the front room’s fun, but can get very loud.

You’d be remiss not to at some point weave through the pretty Piazza della Passera, and downright self-denying not to pop into tiny __[Gelateria della Passera](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/florence/gelateria-della-passera)__, where the flavors rotate every few days but are all based on 100% organic ingredients. The *menta – a fior di latte*base mixed with generous amounts of fresh-pestled spearmint – is pure heaven. 


[#image: /photos/548f623f860c74c1162c9c5a]||||||





##Day 2

__STAY__

__[Palazzo Vecchietti](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/florence/palazzo-vecchietti)__ feels more like chic serviced apartments than a hotel – particularly if you book a one-bedroom suite (some even have small fireplaces). Small, hidden Boffi kitchens and the clean-lined designs of local tastemaker Michele Bonan (whose first, and still greatest, *capolavoro*is JK Place; see above) make it the go-to for fashion executives and creatives who know the city already. The central location, across from the Palazzo Strozzi museum and half a block from Via Tornabuoni, doesn’t hurt. 

__EAT__

__[Trattoria Sostanza](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/florence/trattoria-sostanza-il-troia)__ has an old-school burnish that tourists love; but that patina’s the real deal, testament to the 150-plus years Sostanza has been a stalwart on the Florentine dining scene. Don’t come expecting refinement or culinary fireworks, or you’ll be disappointed. But if silky *tortellini in brodo,*wild-boar ragu, and flame-roasted hen with sage and rosemary potatoes sound good to you, get here before 1 pm to secure your table.

__PLAY__

The __[Mercato Centrale](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/florence/mercato-centrale)__, in Florence’s old-Renaissance San Lorenzo district, recently got a total makeover, taking its formerly staid traditional arched-iron food halls to a new entertainment-meets-retails-meets-gastronomy emporium, with live music, cooking demonstrations, chef appearances and generally a newly-minted vibe of celebration. (If you’re airbnb-ing, you’ll still find the finest produce in town here, so make it your actual market.)

Once your inner chef’s been awakened by all the gorgeous foodstuffs, it’s a 15-minute walk across the Arno to __[Desinare](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/florence/desinare)__, Florence’s newest and coolest cooking school/kitchen shop/ad-hoc dining room. Classes move beyond standard pasta and pastry tutelage and into food styling and photography; the space, designed by co-owner Riccardo Barthel, is a wabi-sabi dream of state-of-the-art stoves and cooktops, ornate maiolica tiles, and antiques. 

__DRINK__

Sweet, rustic __[Le Volpi e L’Uva](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/florence/le-volpi-e-l-uva)__ sits in a tiny and crooked *piazzetta*about 50 yards from the Ponte Vecchio; for over 20 years it’s been pouring small-production wines – some of them downright obscure – from all the major Italian regions. Grab a (slightly rickety) table under the awning and sample a big sangiovese from Montecucco, a flowery ribolla gialla from Friuli, or any of the other dozens of unexpected varietals and micro-specialties offered by the glass.


[#image: /photos/548f604b860c74c1162c9bbf]||||||





##Day 3

__STAY__

__[Riva Lofts](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/florence/riva-lofts-florence)__ puts a bit of cool, quiet distance between its guests and the throng of Florence’s center with its placid, riverside location, across from the Cascine Gardens. Architect Claudio Nardi converted a former factory about half a mile outside the old city walls into 11 rooms and suites that delight with spare but elegant décor – wide oak plank floors, a mix of midcentury finds and contemporary furniture of Nardi’s own design, and thick indulgent linens hanging at windows and draping beds. 

__EAT__

On the Via Tornabuoni—Florence’s Madison Avenue—is __[Procacci](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/florence/procacci)__, a tiny place with an outsized role in the Florence of the sophisticated tourist, for whom a snack of one of its tiny truffle-butter sandwiches is virtually a rite of passage. (It was awarded a royal seal for its deliciousness, back when Italy was still a kingdom – so, yes, Procacci has been cool since the mid 19th century.) It’s the perfect place for a late-morning repast after an hour or two of window-browsing.

__PLAY__

A ten-minute stroll away, across the Piazza della Signoria, is the __[Gucci Museum](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/florence/gucci-museum)__. Opened in 2011, it tells the story of the Florentine fashion house and provides context for its contemporary identity, with showcases of film and fine art (many of the works are on loan from Henri Pinault – chairman of Kering, which luxury conglomerate owns Gucci), as well as more straightforward displays of artisan craftsmanship that celebrate Gucci’s signature motifs (bamboo; floral patterns). Collectors’ note: The ground floor boutique sells a handful of items – classic bags, belts, boots – produced exclusively for the museum.

The __[Fondazione Palazzo Strozzi](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/florence/palazzo-strozzi)__ is a testament in bricks and mortar to the good that happens when the public and private sectors align for the benefit of culture (Ferragamos and municipal ministers sit side by side on the executive board). 25,000 paying visitors a month can’t be wrong about this museum: a spin through the first-floor galleries reveals there’s always something worth seeing – whether a comprehensive Bronzino retrospective, or a Picasso one (showing through January). The curators have created Florence’s most kid-friendly venue: the “Let’s Talk About Art” and Design Room programs incorporate interaction and participation in thoroughly 21st-century ways. 

By now—with all due respect to the Cradle of the Renaissance—you’re probably feeling a little Renaissance’d out. Time for 21st-century Florence. Conveniently enough, downstairs in the basement of the Palazzo Strozzi is __[La Strozzina/Center for Contemporary Culture](http:///www.cntraveler.com/activities/florence/la-strozzina-center-for-contemporary-culture)__, the city’s excellent contemporary art museum. You’ll find conventional exhibitions of photography and fine art, but also readings (Michael Cunningham and Jonathan Lethem recently read the works of Italian poets), dance performances, and seasonal installations by the likes of video artist Mark Formanek. 

__EAT & DRINK__

The natural Florentine affinity for straightforward, rustic cuisine often tends to rule out the need for formal dining in the city. But __[La Bottega del Buon Café](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/florence/la-bottega-del-buon-cafe)__ is a new, and notable exception – not least because it’s brought to you by the team behind the gorgeous Borgo San Pietro hotel in southern Tuscany. Everything you’ll eat (except for the carefully sourced fish) is grown or raised on the restaurant’s farm. Expect refined versions of *tagliato all fiorentina, ribollita*(the throw-it-all-in bread and vegetable soup), flame-roasted pigeon, and others.

miniGuides.seoDescription: Spend a weekend exploring Florence's best things to do, including its Renaissance monuments, and wonderful shopping and dining options.

play.hed: Photos: Exploring Florence, Italy From a Different Angle
play.dek: Photographer Pari Dukovic captures the beauty of Florence landmarks like Michelangelo's *David,* Cappella dei Principi, and the Ponte Vecchio in such a way that makes you reconsider the popular destination—recently voted the [world's no. 1 city](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-20/top-25-cities-in-the-world-readers-choice-awards-2014/25) by Condé Nast Traveler readers—through a new lens.

items.caption:
The Ponte Vecchio is one of Europe’s most storied bridges. Hitler spared it; Robert Kennedy helped
restore it after the 1966 flood; and in 2006, the city
removed 5,000 padlocks (“love locks”) from it and instituted a fine for any additions.

In the Piazza della Signoria, there's a replica of Michelangelo’s *David*—one of two in Florence (the other is in the Piazzale Michelangelo). The original was moved indoors, to the Accademia di Belle Arti, in 1873.

The Baroque interior of the Cappella dei Principi,
a mausoleum commissioned by the Medici family, is inlaid with colored marble and semiprecious stones—an intensely intricate form of mosaic known as *pietre dure.*
Florence’s cathedral, the Basilica of Santa Maria del Fiore.

The Basilica of Santa Maria del Santo Spirito
(designed by Filippo Brunelleschi, who built Santa Maria del Fiore’s famous dome), and nuns in the city’s old center.
Michelangelo’s *David,* in the Accademia di Belle Arti.
The statue’s left foot was damaged in 1991 by a vandal who had smuggled a hammer into the museum.
For more about Florence, Italy, see [author David Leavitt's love letter to the city](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-10-21/florence-a-love-story).

play.hed: 10 Best Things to Do in Florence Right Now
play.dek: Condé Nast Traveler readers voted [Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-10-21/florence-a-love-story) the [no. 1 city in the world](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-20/top-25-cities-in-the-world-readers-choice-awards-2014/25) in the 2014 Readers' Choice Awards—here are the 10 spots you need to visit right now.

items.title: [Portrait Firenze](http://lungarnocollection.com)
items.caption: The latest property from the Ferragamo family, this hideaway right on the Arno river has sensational views of the Ponte Vecchio from the large suites, chic interiors from designer Michele Bonan, and an intimate atmosphere that doesn't feel touristy at all.

items.title: [Mercato Centrale](http://mercatocentrale.it)
items.caption: On the second floor of Florence’s Central Market, food vendors and restaurants showcase the best products and dishes from Tuscany—don’t miss the third-generation fishmonger who cooks your catch of the day right in front of you, and the ice-cream vendor who lists the provenance of each ingredient.

items.title: [Desinare](http://desinare.it)
items.caption: This new state-of-the-art cooking school sits on top of one of the city’s best vintage and design shops. After studying Tuscan classics with celeb chef Arturo Dori (who used to helm foodie favorite Cavalo Nero), you can shop for antiques, state of the art knives, and Florentine tableware.

items.title: [La Bottega del Buon Caffe](http://labottegadelbuoncaffe.com)
items.caption: The owners of Borgo Santo Pietro, a luxury resort in Tuscany, have just re-launched this beloved classic restaurant in a new location, showcasing farm to table ingredients. Don’t miss seasonal pastas like the mouth-watering pumpkin ravioli.

items.title: [Amblé](http://amble.it)
items.caption: This stylish cafe and bar opened a year ago, and has since become the go-to coffee and *aperitivo* spot for fashionable locals. While sipping your Aperol spritz, browse the selection of retro-chic furniture that's also for sale.

items.title: [Marie Antoinette Firenze](http://marieantoinettefirenze.com)
items.caption: With vintage pieces alongside duds from designers like Marni—in a tiny but perfectly edited shop behind the Arno—this new shopping must showcases the mix of contemporary and classic that Florence excels at.

items.title: [La Toraia](http://latoraia.com)
items.caption: The food truck trend has come to Florence: At this mobile eatery, you can sample hamburgers made from the excellent local Chianina beef, and wash them down with local wine. Best of all, the tomato-red truck stays open until midnight, in case you get peckish late night.

items.title: [Gucci Museum](http://guccimuseo.com)
items.caption: Art museums aren't the only culture you'll find in Florence. This museum, devoted to the history of the Gucci line, opened in 2011, and showcases delectable gowns, vintage luggage and even Gucci-logoed surf boards. Fashion hounds will also want to make a pilgrimage to the nearby [Ferragamo Museum](http://www.ferragamo.com/museo/it/ita), a shrine to the Florentine’s family’s impact on both the city’s and world fashion.

items.title: [Rivalta Cafe](http://rivaltacafe.it)
items.caption: Fashion designers and models convene at this new bar and restaurant on the river to exchange the latest gossip and to check out each others’ outfits. Arrive early if you want one of the prime outdoor tables at cocktail hour.

items.title: [Il Gelato di Carapina](http://carapina.it)
items.caption: Conveniently located between the Ponte Vecchio and Uffizi Gallery, this new gelateria happens to also be one of the city’s best, with the creamy confection made in-house daily. Among our favorite flavors: the hazelnut and pistachio, and watermelon when it is in season.

fields.shortBio: Contributing editor [Ondine Cohane](www.ondinecohane.com) is based in Tuscany—when not doing a round-the-world trip each winter.
fields.bio: After [Ondine Cohane](www.ondinecohane.com) edited *Conde Nast Traveler's* Word of Mouth section for a couple of years, she got her dream job, a gig as a contributing editor at the magazine. Eating great food, drinking excellent wine, discovering small hotels, exploring far-flung destinations are all part of the gig, and what she loves. Ondine was previously at *New York* magazine, and frequently writes for *The New York Times* travel section as well as *Lonny, Details,* and other magazines. Before Columbia College and Brearley, Ondine's family moved every couple of years, which may partially explain the wanderlust.

play.hed: What to Do in Florence: 9 Things Locals Love
play.dek: The founder of Mercato Centrale, the creative director of Salvatore Ferragamo, and leather craftsman Tommaso Melani show us their favorite spots to shop, eat, and drink in their hometown.
play.body:
[#image: /photos/544917f4b2a366564bff0e6d]|||
Florence's Uffizi is a first stop for many visitors—but that's not necessarily where the locals hang out.
|||





Three Florentines show us their favorite spots to shop, eat, and drink in their hometown.


__MASSIMILIANO GIORNETTI__

*Creative Director, Salvatore Ferragamo*

“I love living in a small city with such a rich artistic past, where there’s the possibility of having an aperitivo alongside a Renaissance palazzo.”

__Cibrèo__: Chef Fabio Picchi offers light versions of Florentine classics like pappa al pomodoro, a tomato soup, and ribollita, the famous Tuscan stew *(Via del Verrocchio 8r; 39-055-234-1100; entrées from $79).*


__Sostanza__: A nineteenth-century institution with white tiles and traditional dishes.
It’s like eating at home *(Via del Porcellana 25r; 39-055-212-691; entrées from $27).*


__Procacci__: This icon from 1885 has survived globalization. It’s a sort of upscale deli, with oak paneling, marble tables, and the most delicious sandwiches *(Via Tornabuoni 64r; 39-055-211-656).*


----------


__TOMMASO MELANI__

*Leather craftsman and owner of Stefano Bemer*

“Florence’s best artisanal shops have a smaller-scale laboratory feel and remain family-owned.”

__Scuola del Cuoio__: This leather school was started after World War II by leather-making families alongside Franciscan monks. The school is right behind Santa Croce, and you can buy leather accessories in the on-site shop *(Via San Giuseppe 5r; 39-055-244-533).*

__Alessandro Dari__: All his jewelry is handmade, ensuring that each piece is unique—like a sculpture *(Via S. Niccolò 115r; 39-055-244-747).*

__Lorenzo Villoresi__: He is the creator of some of the most interesting and unique perfumes and lotions in the city *(Via de Bardi 14; 39-055-234-1187).*


----------


__UMBERTO MONTANO__

*Founder, Mercato Centrale, a new food hall in the San Lorenzo neighborhood*

“Among the best aspects of eating in Florence
are the organic and seasonal purveyors who keep the food local.”

__Alle Murate__ (above): Housed within the frescoed Palazzo dell’Arte dei Giudici e Notai, this is the best restaurant in town *(Via del Proconsolo 16r; 39-055-240-618; entrées from $45).*

__Osteria del Caffè Italiano__: It has the highest- quality Chianina, Tuscany’s local beef, grilled on wood charcoal *(Via Isola delle Stinche 11/13r; 39-055-289-080; entrées from $10).*

__Desinare__: The new state-of-the-art cooking school is also home to the city’s best vintage and design shop for Florentine tableware and knives *(Via Dei Serragli 234/r; 39-055-221-118*).
