shop.dek: Jewelry designer Caroline Ventura takes us to her favorite places in Florence.
shop.hed: Florence’s Best Perfume, Panino, and Prosecco According to Jewelry Designer Caroline Ventura

items.title: Mercato Centrale
items.caption: “Anytime I’m in a new city one of the first places I like to go is the local market, and Mercato Centrale never disappoints. Don't bother with the guys selling leather goods out front, go inside the market and head straight to [da Nerbone](https://plus.google.com/102720141304039120434/about?gl=us&hl=en) for a Bollito panino (roast beef sandwich). Get it with the salsa verde and a side of artichokes, and then dream about it for the rest of the day. The line can get long so get there when they open. You can use that as your excuse for eating a meat sandwich for breakfast.” _(Piazza del Mercato Centrale)_

items.title: [Il Santino](https://plus.google.com/118085831901545603331/about?gl=us&hl=en)
items.caption: “Il Santino feels like that secret spot you just accidentally happened upon. It's tiny, filled with locals, and they keep your wine glass full, which is basically the Italian trifecta. I found myself coming here more than once during my weeklong stay because it's just a great place to hang out and eat lots of little plates of local food. Highlights include: brandade with fresh shaved olives, lardo pomodoro, the best thinly sliced cinghiale, and the cute bartender, Emiliano.” _(60r Via di Santo Spirito)_

items.title: [Aqua Flor](https://www.facebook.com/pages/Flor-Firenze/101942789905232)
items.caption: “One of the things you must (must!) bring home with you from Florence is a bottle of perfume. Everyone will tell you to not miss Santa Maria Novella, and you shouldn’t, but for me the best place to buy perfume in Florence is Aqua Flor. Inside it's perfume paradise—soaps, lotions, and bottle after bottle of fragrance. The girls who work there will patiently take you through as many scents as you wish to try and help you find the perfect one. You can also make an appointment with the master perfumier and create a one of a kind fragrance, just for you. They will keep the recipe archived and can make a new bottle any time you need. The best part: you can only get Aqua Flor fragrances at Aqua Flor, and there's only one shop. Super special.” _(6 Borgo Santa Croce)_

items.title: [Procacci](http://www.procacci1885.it/)
items.caption: “Procacci is the place to head for a late afternoon snack when you are a little worn out from walking.  They make these really perfect, tiny sandwiches and three or four of them are just the right size to curb any hunger pangs. I've only ordered the _tartufato _panino because it's so good and pairs perfectly with a glass (or two) of Prosecco. This place is really teeny, but if you go there around 3 or 4 p.m. and it shouldn't be too crowded.” _(64 Tornabuoni)_

items.title: [Al Tranvai](http://www.altranvai.it/)
items.caption: “This restaurant is a little off the beaten path but so worth the hike. It was the perfect Italian trattoria experience: grandma in the back cooking, the boisterous owner doing the front of the house, and the menu written only in Italian on chalkboards at your table. If there is involtini di verza on the menu that night, do not miss it. It's basically steamed cabbage stuffed with meat, which sounds ordinary but, I promise you, it's not. Also, if tripe is your thing (it's mine), order the _trippa gratinata_. If tripe isn't your thing, order it anyway and you'll quickly forget that you are eating cow stomach because whatever grandma does to that stuff in the back is magic. Get some homemade walnut liqueur to wash everything down after you finish eating.” _(14r Piazza Torquato Tasso)_

items.title: [Basilica di San Miniato al Monte](http://www.sanminiatoalmonte.it/)
items.caption:
“Most everyone who visits Florence goes to see the Duomo—for good reason—but Basilica di San Miniato al Monte is my favorite church. It's situated on a hill just a tad outside the city and you're greeted with the most wonderful view of the entire city, including the Duomo. The cemetery below the church is a wonderful place to do a bit of self-reflection and pay homage to wonderful Italians (the Franco Zeffirelli family tomb is there). Up the steps from the cemetery is the Basillica. There are no lights at all inside the church, so the light streaming through the many tiny windows is pretty awe-inspiring.” _(34 Via del Monte alle Croci)_




**Related Articles:**_
_

fields.caption: “One of the things you must (must!) bring home with you from Florence is a bottle of perfume. Everyone will tell you to not miss Santa Maria Novella, and you shouldn’t, but for me the best place to buy perfume in Florence is Aqua Flor. Inside it's perfume paradise—soaps, lotions, and bottle after bottle of fragrance. The girls who work there will patiently take you through as many scents as you wish to try and help you find the perfect one. You can also make an appointment with the master perfumier and create a one of a kind fragrance, just for you. They will keep the recipe archived and can make a new bottle any time you need. The best part: you can only get Aqua Flor fragrances at Aqua Flor, and there's only one shop. Super special.” _(6 Borgo Santa Croce)_

shop.socialTitle: An Insider’s Guide to Shopping in Florence
shop.socialDescription: Shopping addicts everywhere need to take a trip to Florence at some point in their lives. The city’s boutiques and luxury stores are all worth a visit—even if you walk away empty-handed.
shop.body:
[#image: /photos/53ec0caf976f8f2d44d5ac17]||||||

_Erica Chan Coffman of [Honestly WTF](http://honestlywtf.com/) shares her favorite shopping haunts in Florence, including a beautiful pharmacy and amazing outlet bargains. _



My love affair with Florence flourished on a recent 72-hour jaunt to the city. Between visiting the Uffizi Gallery, climbing to the top of the Duomo, and enjoying the city's best truffle pasta, I managed to reserve enough time to visit my favorite boutiques, thanks to the ease of getting around this surprisingly quaint city. And with a culture as rich and as deep as Florence’s, some of these shops are worth appreciating even if you walk away empty-handed. These are my picks for Florence's can't-miss shops.















[Officina Profumo Farmaceutica di Santa Maria Novella](http://www.smnovella.it/)



 The Santa Maria Novella Perfumery is one of the oldest and most stunning pharmacies in the world. The Dominican monks of Florence were developing remedies and potions as far back as 1212, using herbs from the monastery gardens. Today, among walls of frescos and 17th-century cabinetry, the historic store and museum stocks an incredible selection of perfumes, soaps, elixirs, and potpourri. _(Via della Scala, 16; +39.055.216276)_

[#image: /photos/53ec0cad976f8f2d44d5ac05]||||||

[Luisa Via Roma](http://www.luisaviaroma.com/)



 Andrea Panconesi's innovative spirit has kept Luisa Via Roma at the forefront of women and men’s luxury fashion since the 1960s. The three-story boutique, which sits across the street from the Duomo, carries looks fresh off the runway as well as wares from up-and-coming European designers. Shopping at Luisa Via Roma is an experience the minute you walk through the door, and you're guaranteed to leave with something for yourself, or—at the very least—inspiration to treat yourself. _(Via Roma, 29/21R; +39.055.90.64.116)_







[The Mall](http://www.themall.it/it/outlet-toscana/homepage.html)  

If you've made it all the way to Florence, it's worth your while to make the 40-minute trek to The Mall, the most famous shopping outlet in Tuscany. Luxury bargains await there: The Prada outlet is not to be missed—and neither are Gucci, Ferragamo, Balenciaga, Valentino, Miu Miu, Marni, and many, many others._ (Via Europa 8; +39.055.8657.775)_



[Madova](http://www.madova.com/)  

These Florentine glovemakers have been crafting leather gloves—lined with cashmere, rabbit fur, silk, and lambswool—since 1919. Madova, which has been run by the same family for four generations, is the only shop in Florence that produces the gloves in-house. The quality is unmatched, and you're sure to find the perfect pair in any size, shape, and color. _(Via Guicciardini 1/R; +39.055.2396526)_







[Antico Setificio Fiorentino](http://anticosetificiofiorentino.com/)  

This silk-weaving workshop is deeply rooted in Florentine history: It's been operating since 1786, and some of the work is done on looms designed by Leonardo da Vinci. The workshop produces some of the most sumptuous silk brocades, damask, taffeta, and lampas in the world. Even if you're not in the market for textiles, it's worth visiting this unique piece of the city's past. _(Via L. Bartolini, 4—by appointment only; +39.055.213861)_







[Elio Ferraro](http://www.elioferraro.com/)  

Vintage clothing and furniture is carefully selected and thoughtfully curated at Elio Ferraro. Expect to find rare and exquisite pieces from Chanel, Missoni, Celine, and Schiaparelli, as well as an impressive collection of housewares from the ’50s to the ’80s. _(Via Pietro Maroncelli 1; +39.02.43113202)_



[Il Papiro](http://www.ilpapirofirenze.it/)  

Purchasing Florentine paper is a must when visiting Florence. This quaint little shop specializes in marbled and patterned paper, cards, stationary, and leather-bound journals. If you're lucky, you might catch one of the owners demonstrating the traditional technique of marbling paper. _(Via Cavour 29/R; +39.055.6499151)_







[Procacci](http://www.procacci1885.it/)  

Procacci is a century-old delicatessen and a food-lover's paradise. It's the perfect place for an aperitif—and while you're there, be sure to sample the shop's famous mini truffle sandwich. If you're just in the mood to browse, you can take home whole truffles, wine, and other specialty food items. _(Via Tornabuoni, 64/R; +39.055.211656)_

fields.name: Erica Chan Coffman
fields.shortBio: Erica Chan Coffman is the founder and editor in chief of [HonestlyWTF](http://honestlywtf.com/) and [HonestlyYUM](http://honestlyyum.com/).
fields.bio: Erica Chan Coffman is the editor in chief of [HonestlyWTF](http://honestlywtf.com/), a lifestyle blog with a global following. Beautifully curated stories covering style, art, travel, home decor, and DIY are awe-inspiring and inspirational. Erica also oversees [HonestlyYUM](http://honestlyyum.com/), a culinary destination for seasonal food and cocktail recipes and entertaining ideas. When she's not working from her home in Oakland, CA, she is globetrotting with her husband and toddler.

shop.body:
## Matt Hranek—writer, photographer, and host of the television series _Alternate Route_—spent five days in Tuscany exploring boutiques, wineries, and open-air markets. Here's a look at what made it into his suitcase.

[#image: /photos/53da87fddcd5888e145ba508]||||||





A monogrammed cotton apron, customized on the spot in Florence’s famous [Mercato Centrale di San Lorenzo](http://www.cntraveler.com/iconic-trips/2010/09/Five-Perfect-Days-in-Tuscany) ($22).







The Florentia stationery set from the legendary paper shop [Pineider](http://www.pineider.com/home.pag) (Piazza de’ Rucellai 4/7r; $61).







****An easy-to-pack bottle of extra-virgin olive oil sourced from Tuscan groves, at [Castello di Casole’s Pazzia bistro](http://www.castellodicasole.com/pazzia-pizzeria) ($17).







****A bottle of Chianti Classico Riserva from the 600-year-old winery [Antinori](http://www.antinori.it/) ($35).







****Sun-dried porcini mushrooms from the Mercato Centrale ($14).







****A buttery leather pouch from [Il Bisonte](http://www.ilbisonte.com/eng/2013_the_diary.php) (Via del Parione 31/33r; $88).







****A handmade, hand-dyed leather bracelet from Il Bisonte ($78).







****White-truffle salt from the [Comune di Montaione](http://www.comune.montaione.fi.it/), in a small town an hour west of Florence (Piazza del Municipio, Montaione; $14).

fields.name: Matt Hranek
fields.shortBio: Matthew Hranek is a contributing editor at Conde Nast Traveler.
fields.bio: Matthew Hranek is a full time traveller, explorer, eater, and drinker. He is also a part time photographer, film maker, blogger, contributing Conde Nast Traveler editor, and occasional TV host. Matthew has 20 years experience navigating airports, train stations, hotels, restaurants, and bars worldwide. Mostly on the road and with his ear to the ground, he is inspired by the old school as well as the new. He is constantly on the forage. Follow him on his blog, [The William Brown Project](http://www.thewilliambrownproject.com/).

featuredStays.name: Four Seasons Hotel Firenze
featuredStays.description: The 11-acre botanical garden that is home to these two restored Renaissance buildings—a fifteenth-century palazzo and a sixteenth-century convent. Rooms with frescoes and ceiling murals have amenities made by a Florence-based perfumer, and public areas showcase Renaissance art. Dine alfresco at Il Palagio, which uses locally sourced ingredients. The Winery serves more than 50 Italian wines by the glass and has a list of nearly 400 bottles. Stroll tree-lined paths to the two-story herbal spa, where wet-treatment rooms have glass mosaic walls and floors.
featuredStays.shortDescription: A hotel steeped in history, where rooms are covered in frescoes and ceiling murals.

featuredStays.name: J.K. Place Firenze
featuredStays.description: J.K. Place Firenze has a great location on Piazza Santa Maria Novella, with a front terrace where the hotel serves a generous and tasty brunch on weekends. Rooms range from cozy doubles to the first-floor front suite, with its massive canopied bed and three French doors that open onto the square. The décor is terrifically chic, with large-scale photos by Massimo Listri throughout.
featuredStays.shortDescription: A prime central hotel, with a front terrace that hums on weekends.

featuredStays.name: Belmond Villa San Michele
featuredStays.description: A former monastery on a cliffside amid trees and terraced gardens just outside Florence. Historians attribute the villa’s facade—which dates to the fifteenth century—to Michelangelo. Floral arrangements in large ceramic vases line the floors of corridors with arched ceilings. Service is superb, and the terrace of the restaurant Loggia is offers delicious takes on regional cuisine.
featuredStays.shortDescription: You can't beat the ambiance—or the views—at this former monastery outside the city.

fields.caption:
You cannot beat the ambience at this former monastery on a cliffside amid trees and terraced gardens just outside Florence. Suites come with "unbelievable views of the City of Lilies."







**Overall score: 97.5**







_See full rating information for **[Villa San Michele, Fiesole](/hotels/europe/italy/villa-san-michele-fiesole-tuscany-italy)**_

featuredStays.name: Riva Lofts Florence
featuredStays.description: Designed by Florentine architect Claudio Nardi, this is a striking eight-room property in a refurbished nineteenth-century factory on the southern bank of the Arno, just removed from the city center. The combination of spare, loftlike rooms with in-suite kitchens and a common room with an honor bar and a fireplace creates the feel of stylish Florentine apartments. Nardi’s design mixes natural woods and various stone surfaces with an eclectic assortment of furniture that includes white leather sofas, cowhide rugs, and oversize lamps and mirrors. Alice Nardi, the resourceful owner (and the architect’s daughter), can recommend everything from little-known restaurants to a barbershop, and the hotel has bicycles to help get you around town.
featuredStays.shortDescription: This small hotel is a fresh counterpart to the city’s more prevalent traditional design.

related.body:
[#image: /photos/53e2f229dddaa35c30f65e91]||||||

**You can’t leave Florence without eating…**



 A tripe sandwich. When musing about food in Florence, most people dream of steak—the renowned bistecca fiorentina—but I reach deeper into the cow and go for any one of its four stomachs. Traditionally, Florentines have been obsessively fond of tripe (and just about other any innards), and no one cooks it better. Trust me, there’s no funkiness, nothing to make your stomach quiver. One of the world’s great dishes is the tomato-sauced_ trippa alla fiorentina_, but there’s even more pleasure in something that most travelers miss: a warm tripe panino on a crusty roll, bought from a food truck or cart and eaten on the street.



**How to order:** A well-stocked tripe wagon will have a surprisingly diverse menu of offal, starring a few different kinds of tripe including the classic of Florence classics (and my favorite): _lampredotto_, made from the ruminant’s fourth stomach. Ask for the roll to be _bagnato_ (dipped in the cooking broth) and garnished with green sauce: salsa verde, typically made of mixed herbs, anchovies, capers, garlic, olive oil, and a little vinegar and/or mustard for extra sparkle. For a drink, I’d opt for a glass of white wine or, on a really hot day, a beer.





[#image: /photos/53e2f229c2d3f39d3610b4a0]|||Vegetarians, beware.|||

**How to eat it:** First, put aside any memories you may have (or think you have) of stinky tripe. Properly prepared behind the scenes, then cooked to tenderness in flavorful, salty broth and served warm, lampredotto will remind you more of super-tender juicy corned brisket than of a so-called variety meat. The salsa verde functions like the mustard on a deli sandwich, but with a more complex flavor. These panini can sometimes be topped with seasonal vegetables too, such as simmered leeks or artichokes, but I prefer my lampredotto clear of distractions. Near the food truck, there will be benches or even a counter on which to lean; if not, just stand there like the other customers. Lean forward so the juice doesn’t drip on your shirt and be sure to have plenty of paper napkins at the ready. Beyond that, heck, it’s a sandwich, and you’ve been eating those since you were two years old.







**Where to find one:** There’s no longer a _trippaio_ on every street corner in Florence. The tradition is robust, but invasive species like hamburgers impinge on its popularity. Still, there are quite a few scattered around the city—wherever there are lawyers or construction workers on a lunch break (this is not a dinner-time tradition). There’s even a small (but good) trippaio right outside one of the town’s best restaurants, Cibrèo, on via dei Macci. But my favorite tripe man is Mario Albergucci, whose elaborate fold-out truck is to be found at the Porta Romana, south of the Pitti Palace and the Boboli Gardens. Like his impeccably clean wagon, his repertoire is larger than average, going beyond tripe to include, for instance, _poppa_ (udder) and even tender simmered beef, veal, or pork for those who just can’t cope with the facts of Florentine life.



**More travel etiquette:**



[The Dish You Should Never Order in Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/05/the-best-food-in-rome)







 [The One Dish to Eat in Naples, Italy](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/06/food-etiquette-guide-eating-in-naples)

related.hed: What to Do in Florence: 9 Things Locals Love
related.dek: The founder of Mercato Centrale, the creative director of Salvatore Ferragamo, and leather craftsman Tommaso Melani show us their favorite spots to shop, eat, and drink in their hometown.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/544917f4b2a366564bff0e6d]|||
Florence's Uffizi is a first stop for many visitors—but that's not necessarily where the locals hang out.
|||





Three Florentines show us their favorite spots to shop, eat, and drink in their hometown.


__MASSIMILIANO GIORNETTI__

*Creative Director, Salvatore Ferragamo*

“I love living in a small city with such a rich artistic past, where there’s the possibility of having an aperitivo alongside a Renaissance palazzo.”

__Cibrèo__: Chef Fabio Picchi offers light versions of Florentine classics like pappa al pomodoro, a tomato soup, and ribollita, the famous Tuscan stew *(Via del Verrocchio 8r; 39-055-234-1100; entrées from $79).*


__Sostanza__: A nineteenth-century institution with white tiles and traditional dishes.
It’s like eating at home *(Via del Porcellana 25r; 39-055-212-691; entrées from $27).*


__Procacci__: This icon from 1885 has survived globalization. It’s a sort of upscale deli, with oak paneling, marble tables, and the most delicious sandwiches *(Via Tornabuoni 64r; 39-055-211-656).*


----------


__TOMMASO MELANI__

*Leather craftsman and owner of Stefano Bemer*

“Florence’s best artisanal shops have a smaller-scale laboratory feel and remain family-owned.”

__Scuola del Cuoio__: This leather school was started after World War II by leather-making families alongside Franciscan monks. The school is right behind Santa Croce, and you can buy leather accessories in the on-site shop *(Via San Giuseppe 5r; 39-055-244-533).*

__Alessandro Dari__: All his jewelry is handmade, ensuring that each piece is unique—like a sculpture *(Via S. Niccolò 115r; 39-055-244-747).*

__Lorenzo Villoresi__: He is the creator of some of the most interesting and unique perfumes and lotions in the city *(Via de Bardi 14; 39-055-234-1187).*


----------


__UMBERTO MONTANO__

*Founder, Mercato Centrale, a new food hall in the San Lorenzo neighborhood*

“Among the best aspects of eating in Florence
are the organic and seasonal purveyors who keep the food local.”

__Alle Murate__ (above): Housed within the frescoed Palazzo dell’Arte dei Giudici e Notai, this is the best restaurant in town *(Via del Proconsolo 16r; 39-055-240-618; entrées from $45).*

__Osteria del Caffè Italiano__: It has the highest- quality Chianina, Tuscany’s local beef, grilled on wood charcoal *(Via Isola delle Stinche 11/13r; 39-055-289-080; entrées from $10).*

__Desinare__: The new state-of-the-art cooking school is also home to the city’s best vintage and design shop for Florentine tableware and knives *(Via Dei Serragli 234/r; 39-055-221-118*).

fields.name: Ondine Cohane
fields.shortBio: Contributing editor [Ondine Cohane](www.ondinecohane.com) is based in Tuscany—when not doing a round-the-world trip each winter.
fields.bio: After [Ondine Cohane](www.ondinecohane.com) edited *Conde Nast Traveler's* Word of Mouth section for a couple of years, she got her dream job, a gig as a contributing editor at the magazine. Eating great food, drinking excellent wine, discovering small hotels, exploring far-flung destinations are all part of the gig, and what she loves. Ondine was previously at *New York* magazine, and frequently writes for *The New York Times* travel section as well as *Lonny, Details,* and other magazines. Before Columbia College and Brearley, Ondine's family moved every couple of years, which may partially explain the wanderlust.

related.hed: Wine Tasting at Tuscany's Best Wineries
related.dek: If you're looking to sample wine while you're in Italy, go straight to the source: These Tuscan wineries are excellent spots to learn about—and, of course, sample—wine.

related.socialDescription: If you're looking to sample wine while you're in Italy, go straight to the source: These Tuscan wineries are excellent spots to learn about—and, of course, sample—wine.

items.title: Castello Banfi
items.caption:
You might want to set aside an entire weekend for Castello Banfi, a family-owned vineyard estate and winery in Brunello di Montalcino. Though it’s famous for its award-winning Brunellos, syrahs, merlots, cabernets, and blends, you’ll want to stay long after the wine tasting to soak in the spectacular surrounds (the estate boasts 7,000 acres of vineyards, olive groves, and cypress trees). 

--------------

__Vintner’s pick:__ [Poggio all'Oro Brunello di Montalcino](http://castellobanfi.com/en/banfi-wines/castello-banfi/montalcino-red-wines/p@poggio-all-oro)

items.title: Barone Ricasoli
items.caption:
Many say that you won’t get a better Chianti than one from Barone Ricasoli—a pretty lofty claim, but highly probable considering that Baron Bettino Ricasoli himself invented it in 1872. Ricasoli is Italy’s oldest winery, producing some of Tuscany’s finest wine since 1141. To this day, the family continues to produce more than three million bottles a year. The winery offers an excellent tour of its cellars and grounds, including the majestic Castello di Brolio, capped by a private wine tasting.

---------


__Vintner’s pick:__ [Chianti Classico Castello di Brolio](http://www.ricasoli.it/etichette/vini/castello-di-brolio/2011)

items.title: Azienda Agricola Montefioralle
items.caption:
While you’re in the Chianti region, stop by this small, family-run winery in the medieval village of Montefioralle, near Greve. Unlike Barone Ricasoli, this winery produces only 10,000 bottles of wine a year (it’s one of the smallest wineries among the Chianti classico producers) but that’s where its charm lies. A member of the Sieni family, who own the winery, will personally take you on a tour through the vineyards and cellars, followed by a tasting of all six wines produced.

------

__Vintner’s pick:__ [Monteficalle Supertuscan IGT](http://www.aziendamontefioralle.com/igt.html)
items.credit: © LOOK Die Bildagentur der Fotografen GmbH / Alamy

items.title: Marchesi de Frescobaldi Castello di Nipozzano
items.caption:
The iconic Renaissance artists Donatello and Michelozzo Michelozzi were said to be fiercely loyal to the wines produced at Castello di Nipozzano, and we’re inclined to believe it. The winery, located in the heart of the Chianti Rùfina region, pioneered the production of cabernet sauvignon, merlot, cabernet franc and petit verdot in Tuscany in 1855; a century later, they began producing their signature [Mormoreto](http://www.frescobaldi.it/en-us/home/ourwines/mormoreto.aspx). Their wine tour takes you through their cellars and ends with a wine tasting with antipasti.

-------

__Vintner’s pick:__ [Nipozzano Vecchie Viti](http://www.frescobaldi.it/en-us/home/ourwines/nipozzanovecchieviti.aspx)

items.title: Tenuta San Guido
items.caption:
Being the birthplace and exclusive producer of the Sassicaia—one of Italy’s most sought-after wines—Tenuta San Guido is a must for oenophiles. For many years, Sassicaia was simply the personal wine of estate owner Mario Incisa della Rocchetta, until it was released commercially in 1971 (it’s considered the first Super Tuscan). Tenuta San Guido’s cellar tour and wine tasting fee is a steep €60, but worth it.

----------

__Vintner’s pick:__ [Tenuta San Guido Sassicaia](http://www.tenutasanguido.com/Sassicaia.html)
items.credit: © Adams Picture Library t/a apl / Alamy

items.title: Marchesi Antinori
items.caption:
The Antinori family have been making wines since 1385, though their sleek, newly-opened winery—the [Marchesi Antinori Chianti Classico Cellar](http://www.antinorichianticlassico.it/)—is nothing less than a contemporary architectural masterpiece. The winery offers excellent vineyard-to-bottle tours topped off by generous pours at the wine tasting. Antinori’s Tignanello, released in 1971, is still considered one of the world’s greatest wines, and they continue to be one of Tuscany’s most important wine producers today.

-----------

__Vintner’s pick:__ [Marchesi Antinori Tignanello Toscana IGT](http://www.antinori.it/en/26-generazioni/tignanello/tignanello-2011)

items.title: Avignonesi
items.caption:
The stunning Avignonesi winery, located in the village of Valiano near Montepulciano, produces eight red wines ([including an award-winning merlot](http://www.avignonesi.it/en/products/desiderio-cortona-doc/2011)), a chardonnay, and three grappas. The winery boasts one of Italy’s most ancient and beautiful wine cellars, allegedly built in the late 16th century. We recommend the general tour, which takes you through the vineyards, cellar and attic, followed by an excellent four-course meal with wine pairings.

--------

__Vintner’s pick:__ [Vin Santo di Montepulciano DOC 2000](http://www.avignonesi.it/en/products/vin-santo-di-montepulciano-doc/2000)

items.title: Biondi-Santi, Tenuta Il Greppo
items.caption:
Like Barone Ricasoli with Chianti, you can expect to find an excellent bottle of Brunello di Montalcino at Biondi-Santi—it was invented here, after all. Biondi-Santi alone has been producing Brunello continuously since 1888; there are rumors of bottles in their cellar dating back to 1888 and 1891. The two-hour private wine tasting sessions are good but pricey at €50—there’s a shorter, 45-minute version at the cellar for €15 that gives a great overview of their wine-making process and tasting of two wines. 

--------


__Vintner’s pick:__ [Brunello di Montalcino DOCG Vintage](http://www.biondisanti.it/Ita/scheda_brunello_annata.php?anno=2006&tipo=b)

Krisanne grew up in Sydney, Australia and splits her time between New York and Italy.

related.hed: Will Work for Wine: Visiting a Biodynamic Vineyard in Tuscany
related.dek: Andrea Zanfei and Valentina Libri's days are guided by the rhythms of nature. They work with lunar movements and seasons to make natural wines that reflect the personality of their land. Join [Beers and Beans'](http://beersandbeans.com) Randy Kalp and Bethany Salvon as they volunteer at this beautiful biodynamic winery in Tuscany.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/54e27f70560f0bf2218e2f7d]|||
Fattoria Cerreto Libri in Pontassieve, Italy. © Bethany Salvon 
|||






We found Fattoria Cerreto Libri by chance. At the time we were in Paris, France, trying to pick an Italian farm to volunteer on with the [World Wide Opportunities on Organic Farms organization](http://www.wwoof.net) (WWOOF). We only planned to stay a few days, but ended up spending two weeks with Andrea Zanfei and Valentina Libri, helping the couple with the grape harvest—and discovering a different side of the wine industry in the process.

Libri inherited [Fattoria Cerreto Libri](http://www.cerretolibri.it/fclen.html) from her father. It's been in her family since the 18th century, at which time the villas and wine cellar were built. Libri says the vines are more than 40 years old and that she and her husband, Andrea, chose to make the winery biodynamic because of their "desire to defend the land and its history." It's no small task: To be biodynamic isn't just shorthand for "sustainable agriculture" or "organic farming"—it's a harvesting schedule that often defers to the position of the moon, with planting, pruning, and plucking set by the lunar calendar. No chemicals are used, and wines will ideally taste of the *terroir* from which they came. They have personality—as do their growers. 

"Some of the wine world’s big names have been farming biodynamically for years: Domaine Romanée Conti, M. Chapoutier, and Boisset to name a few," writes Katie Kelly Bell in a *Forbes* article about [why biodynamic wines are better for you](http://www.forbes.com/sites/katiebell/2014/04/22/why-biodynamic-wines-are-better-for-you-six-to-try-now/). But it's still not common practice, which makes places like Fattoria Cerreto Libri trendsetters in a heavily regulated industry.

Fattoria Cerreto Libri carves out a vineyard among green hillsides full of olive groves, just outside the small factory town of Pontassieve, Italy, and about 10 miles east of Florence. It is Chianti country: The majority of grapes grown at Fattoria Cerrito Libri are canaiolo and sangiovese, which make up the vineyard's excellent Chianti Rufina—a standout in the densely populated wine region. As of 2012, Italy was home to a little over 10 percent of the world's vineyards by the acre, just behind world leader Spain and France. To distinguish yourself is a challenge, to say the least.

"Our wine is rich and gentle," says Zanfei. "It can be aged for a long time without losing intensity, and is generous and strong." The flavors of his wines are the same you'll find in the vineyard, he adds. Time to find out.

We started work in the vineyards at 8 a.m. each day, just as the fog began to lift. Beads of dew shimmered on the vines and the late-summer sun began to warm the earth. Grapes, when they are mature, are picked by hand and placed into small cases before being taken to the vineyard's wine cellar. Outside the cellar, the stems are removed from the freshly picked grapes. The grapes are then put into glass-lined cement tanks where they start a natural fermentation. After about 20 days, the grape peels are removed and the wine is placed into a smaller aging barrel to finish the fermentation process. We linger as long as we can, though you know the saying: "A watched barrel...".

Though we are there to work, Zanfei and Libri treat us like guests. Zanfei welcomes us into the wine cellar, where he sells his wine in bottles and straight from the barrel. We enjoy, very literally, the fruits of our labor, complemented by Libri's delicious regional cooking and homemade desserts. And no day would be complete without opening (several) bottles of the farm's aromatic wine, including its Chianti Rufina, a spicy, fully formed wine with notes of ripe berries and violet. It’s in the Chianti that we could really taste the personality of the farm. From the herbs to the flowers, to the soil and amount of sun the grapes had received, the soul of Zanfei’s Chianti lingered on our palate like no other.

fields.name: Randy Kalp and Bethany Salvon
fields.shortBio: [Beers and Beans](http://beersandbeans.com/) follows a photographer and a journalist as they travel the world in search of the unusual, mundane, beautiful, and forgotten.
fields.bio:
In August 2010, Randy and Beth from [Beers and Beans](http://beersandbeans.com/) took the first flight of their RTW trip and headed to Iceland! Since then they have been lucky enough to drive across the United States, camp in Iceland, hang out in London, eat their way through Paris, work on an organic farm in Tuscany, and track down long-lost family members in Lacedonia, Italy. Their travel stories have appeared in *Men’s Health*, *USA Today* Travel Tips, *San Diego Uptown News*,
*National Geographic Intelligent Travel*, and other travel websites.

pinterest.hed: How Not to Look Like a Tourist in Florence
pinterest.dek: It’s easy to get lured into an overpriced tourist experience in the [most popular city in the world](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-20/top-25-cities-in-the-world-readers-choice-awards-2014/25), so follow these tips to ensure a more authentic stay in Florence, Italy.
pinterest.seoTitle: How Not To Look Like a Tourist in Florence
pinterest.seoDescription: It’s easy to get caught up in the overpriced tourist traps, so follow these tips to ensure a more authentic Florence experience.
pinterest.socialTitle: How Not To Look Like a Tourist in Florence
pinterest.socialDescription: It’s easy to get caught up in the overpriced tourist traps, so follow these tips to ensure a more authentic Florence experience.
pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/546b855ecbbd2620680daa18]||||||

##How to Greet People

All it takes is a friendly “Ciao” by day and a “Buona sera” in the evening. When meeting someone new, anticipate that they may lean in to give you one light kiss on each cheek. Men usually greet other men with a firm handshake.

##How to Get Around

The most popular way to navigate the ancient (and often cobblestoned) streets of Florence is by bicycle or scooter. Explore a little and look for hidden spots around the city to soak in the views of Ponte Vecchio at night. 

__Scooters:__ 

[Alinari Rental](http://www.alinarirental.com/), Via San Zanobi, 38r (tel. +39-055-280-500). Cost to rent is €15 per hour, €35 for 5 hours, €55 per day for a motorino of 100cc–125cc.  

[Florence by Bike](http://www.florencebybike.it/en/), Via San Zanobi, 120r (tel. +39-055-488-992). Cost to rent is €45 for five hours, €68 per day for a 125cc Honda scooter.

There are also __budget-friendly city bikes__ available at stands around town (find them in the parking lots at Santa Maria Novella rail station, Piazza Santa Croce, Piazza Lorenzo Ghiberti north of Santa Croce, and Campo di Marte train station at Via Mannelli).
 
And remember: Always wear a helmet.

##How to Look the Part

“Fashion in Florence is subtle and simple—colors are beige with dark tones," says Florence-based street photographer [Tiana Kai](http://tianakai.com). "Men love tailored suits and women show less cleavage than one would imagine. Dresses are accompanied with flat boots, Florentine attitude, and dark hair. Embrace and pair simple style with statement sunglasses and an understated leather purse. Don’t forget a scarf!”

[#image: /photos/546b855e2a3d21fa285c765c]||||||

##Local Tips

__DO__ avoid tourist restaurant traps by doing your research. Check out reviews on restaurants in the area, or do things the old-fashioned way by talking to people and asking them where they like to eat. 

__DON'T__ settle for the restaurants right outside the Duomo. Cross the bridge into Santo Spirito and find hole-in-the-wall, family-owned spots for a more authentic Italian experience. Check out [amblé Firenze](http://www.amble.it/main/) on Chiasso dei del Bene for freshly made sandwiches and vintage decor. Stop by [Osteria Santo Spirito](http://www.osteriasantospirito.it/) to indulge in authentic Tuscan cuisine on the Piazza Santo Spirito.

__DO__ choose comfortable yet stylish shoes. Florence is a walking city, so go with a chic pair of leather flats or sandals to keep you comfortable and fashionable. Wearing heels is completely unnecessary. 

__DON'T__ order a cappuccino after 10 a.m. The cappuccino is, culturally, a drink that's only enjoyed in the morning. The fresh whole milk is thought to inhibit digestion.

fields.bio: In April 2013, lifestyle photographer Jinna Yang quit her full-time fashion job to travel the world. She started sharing stories of her adventures on [Grease and Glamour](http://greaseandglamour.com/), helping inspire others to live life with purpose and follow their dreams. Founded in 2012, Grease and Glamour quickly became a platform for endless inspiration, showcasing some of the world's most beautiful destinations. Jinna’s work has been featured in Time Magazine, CNN Travel, Yahoo, BBC World Radio, and hundreds of other media outlets around the world.

pinterest.dek: Shopping addicts everywhere need to take a trip to Florence at some point in their lives. The city’s boutiques and luxury stores are all worth a visit—even if you walk away empty-handed.

pinterest.socialTitle: An Insider’s Guide to Shopping in Florence
pinterest.socialDescription: Shopping addicts everywhere need to take a trip to Florence at some point in their lives. The city’s boutiques and luxury stores are all worth a visit—even if you walk away empty-handed.
pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/53ec0caf976f8f2d44d5ac17]||||||

_Erica Chan Coffman of [Honestly WTF](http://honestlywtf.com/) shares her favorite shopping haunts in Florence, including a beautiful pharmacy and amazing outlet bargains. _



My love affair with Florence flourished on a recent 72-hour jaunt to the city. Between visiting the Uffizi Gallery, climbing to the top of the Duomo, and enjoying the city's best truffle pasta, I managed to reserve enough time to visit my favorite boutiques, thanks to the ease of getting around this surprisingly quaint city. And with a culture as rich and as deep as Florence’s, some of these shops are worth appreciating even if you walk away empty-handed. These are my picks for Florence's can't-miss shops.















[Officina Profumo Farmaceutica di Santa Maria Novella](http://www.smnovella.it/)



 The Santa Maria Novella Perfumery is one of the oldest and most stunning pharmacies in the world. The Dominican monks of Florence were developing remedies and potions as far back as 1212, using herbs from the monastery gardens. Today, among walls of frescos and 17th-century cabinetry, the historic store and museum stocks an incredible selection of perfumes, soaps, elixirs, and potpourri. _(Via della Scala, 16; +39.055.216276)_

[#image: /photos/53ec0cad976f8f2d44d5ac05]||||||

[Luisa Via Roma](http://www.luisaviaroma.com/)



 Andrea Panconesi's innovative spirit has kept Luisa Via Roma at the forefront of women and men’s luxury fashion since the 1960s. The three-story boutique, which sits across the street from the Duomo, carries looks fresh off the runway as well as wares from up-and-coming European designers. Shopping at Luisa Via Roma is an experience the minute you walk through the door, and you're guaranteed to leave with something for yourself, or—at the very least—inspiration to treat yourself. _(Via Roma, 29/21R; +39.055.90.64.116)_







[The Mall](http://www.themall.it/it/outlet-toscana/homepage.html)  

If you've made it all the way to Florence, it's worth your while to make the 40-minute trek to The Mall, the most famous shopping outlet in Tuscany. Luxury bargains await there: The Prada outlet is not to be missed—and neither are Gucci, Ferragamo, Balenciaga, Valentino, Miu Miu, Marni, and many, many others._ (Via Europa 8; +39.055.8657.775)_



[Madova](http://www.madova.com/)  

These Florentine glovemakers have been crafting leather gloves—lined with cashmere, rabbit fur, silk, and lambswool—since 1919. Madova, which has been run by the same family for four generations, is the only shop in Florence that produces the gloves in-house. The quality is unmatched, and you're sure to find the perfect pair in any size, shape, and color. _(Via Guicciardini 1/R; +39.055.2396526)_







[Antico Setificio Fiorentino](http://anticosetificiofiorentino.com/)  

This silk-weaving workshop is deeply rooted in Florentine history: It's been operating since 1786, and some of the work is done on looms designed by Leonardo da Vinci. The workshop produces some of the most sumptuous silk brocades, damask, taffeta, and lampas in the world. Even if you're not in the market for textiles, it's worth visiting this unique piece of the city's past. _(Via L. Bartolini, 4—by appointment only; +39.055.213861)_







[Elio Ferraro](http://www.elioferraro.com/)  

Vintage clothing and furniture is carefully selected and thoughtfully curated at Elio Ferraro. Expect to find rare and exquisite pieces from Chanel, Missoni, Celine, and Schiaparelli, as well as an impressive collection of housewares from the ’50s to the ’80s. _(Via Pietro Maroncelli 1; +39.02.43113202)_



[Il Papiro](http://www.ilpapirofirenze.it/)  

Purchasing Florentine paper is a must when visiting Florence. This quaint little shop specializes in marbled and patterned paper, cards, stationary, and leather-bound journals. If you're lucky, you might catch one of the owners demonstrating the traditional technique of marbling paper. _(Via Cavour 29/R; +39.055.6499151)_







[Procacci](http://www.procacci1885.it/)  

Procacci is a century-old delicatessen and a food-lover's paradise. It's the perfect place for an aperitif—and while you're there, be sure to sample the shop's famous mini truffle sandwich. If you're just in the mood to browse, you can take home whole truffles, wine, and other specialty food items. _(Via Tornabuoni, 64/R; +39.055.211656)_

fields.name: Erica Chan Coffman
fields.shortBio: Erica Chan Coffman is the founder and editor in chief of [HonestlyWTF](http://honestlywtf.com/) and [HonestlyYUM](http://honestlyyum.com/).
fields.bio: Erica Chan Coffman is the editor in chief of [HonestlyWTF](http://honestlywtf.com/), a lifestyle blog with a global following. Beautifully curated stories covering style, art, travel, home decor, and DIY are awe-inspiring and inspirational. Erica also oversees [HonestlyYUM](http://honestlyyum.com/), a culinary destination for seasonal food and cocktail recipes and entertaining ideas. When she's not working from her home in Oakland, CA, she is globetrotting with her husband and toddler.

pinterest.hed: 10 Best Things to Do in Florence Right Now
pinterest.dek: Condé Nast Traveler readers voted [Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-10-21/florence-a-love-story) the [no. 1 city in the world](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-20/top-25-cities-in-the-world-readers-choice-awards-2014/25) in the 2014 Readers' Choice Awards—here are the 10 spots you need to visit right now.

items.title: [Portrait Firenze](http://lungarnocollection.com)
items.caption: The latest property from the Ferragamo family, this hideaway right on the Arno river has sensational views of the Ponte Vecchio from the large suites, chic interiors from designer Michele Bonan, and an intimate atmosphere that doesn't feel touristy at all.

items.title: [Mercato Centrale](http://mercatocentrale.it)
items.caption: On the second floor of Florence’s Central Market, food vendors and restaurants showcase the best products and dishes from Tuscany—don’t miss the third-generation fishmonger who cooks your catch of the day right in front of you, and the ice-cream vendor who lists the provenance of each ingredient.

items.title: [Desinare](http://desinare.it)
items.caption: This new state-of-the-art cooking school sits on top of one of the city’s best vintage and design shops. After studying Tuscan classics with celeb chef Arturo Dori (who used to helm foodie favorite Cavalo Nero), you can shop for antiques, state of the art knives, and Florentine tableware.

items.title: [La Bottega del Buon Caffe](http://labottegadelbuoncaffe.com)
items.caption: The owners of Borgo Santo Pietro, a luxury resort in Tuscany, have just re-launched this beloved classic restaurant in a new location, showcasing farm to table ingredients. Don’t miss seasonal pastas like the mouth-watering pumpkin ravioli.

items.title: [Amblé](http://amble.it)
items.caption: This stylish cafe and bar opened a year ago, and has since become the go-to coffee and *aperitivo* spot for fashionable locals. While sipping your Aperol spritz, browse the selection of retro-chic furniture that's also for sale.

items.title: [Marie Antoinette Firenze](http://marieantoinettefirenze.com)
items.caption: With vintage pieces alongside duds from designers like Marni—in a tiny but perfectly edited shop behind the Arno—this new shopping must showcases the mix of contemporary and classic that Florence excels at.

items.title: [La Toraia](http://latoraia.com)
items.caption: The food truck trend has come to Florence: At this mobile eatery, you can sample hamburgers made from the excellent local Chianina beef, and wash them down with local wine. Best of all, the tomato-red truck stays open until midnight, in case you get peckish late night.

items.title: [Gucci Museum](http://guccimuseo.com)
items.caption: Art museums aren't the only culture you'll find in Florence. This museum, devoted to the history of the Gucci line, opened in 2011, and showcases delectable gowns, vintage luggage and even Gucci-logoed surf boards. Fashion hounds will also want to make a pilgrimage to the nearby [Ferragamo Museum](http://www.ferragamo.com/museo/it/ita), a shrine to the Florentine’s family’s impact on both the city’s and world fashion.

items.title: [Rivalta Cafe](http://rivaltacafe.it)
items.caption: Fashion designers and models convene at this new bar and restaurant on the river to exchange the latest gossip and to check out each others’ outfits. Arrive early if you want one of the prime outdoor tables at cocktail hour.

items.title: [Il Gelato di Carapina](http://carapina.it)
items.caption: Conveniently located between the Ponte Vecchio and Uffizi Gallery, this new gelateria happens to also be one of the city’s best, with the creamy confection made in-house daily. Among our favorite flavors: the hazelnut and pistachio, and watermelon when it is in season.

fields.name: Ondine Cohane
fields.shortBio: Contributing editor [Ondine Cohane](www.ondinecohane.com) is based in Tuscany—when not doing a round-the-world trip each winter.
fields.bio: After [Ondine Cohane](www.ondinecohane.com) edited *Conde Nast Traveler's* Word of Mouth section for a couple of years, she got her dream job, a gig as a contributing editor at the magazine. Eating great food, drinking excellent wine, discovering small hotels, exploring far-flung destinations are all part of the gig, and what she loves. Ondine was previously at *New York* magazine, and frequently writes for *The New York Times* travel section as well as *Lonny, Details,* and other magazines. Before Columbia College and Brearley, Ondine's family moved every couple of years, which may partially explain the wanderlust.
